14 August. Youth marched in Lokoja to demand peaceful and fair gubernatorial elections in Kogi state. [size=500]
15 August. PDP supporters protested in Abuja and demanded release of a social activist arrested earlier. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of Nigeria (2015-) Prison Guards
column17: 15 August. Prisoners in Keffi violently protested the living conditions and tried to escape. Police forces intervened and stopped the attempt. [size=50]
15 August (or around). A group of freight forwarders in Apapa protested the imposition of a levy. [size=no report]

15 August. Women from various communities in Warru South West staged protests at flow stations in the area. The demonstrators demand infrastructure development, job creation and the payment of entitlements. [size=no report]
16 August. People of Obeagu Ugwuaji protested the arrest of their monarch over robbery accusations. [size=500]

On August 16th and 17th, militiamen (accused of being members of the Ebom community, and coded as such) attacked the Usumotong community at an unspecified location in Abi. Soldiers repelled the attackers on both occasions. There are no reports of casualties or fatalities.
17 August. Shitile and Ikurav Militias clashed in three unspecified villages in Katsina Ala LGA. Nine people were killed.
17 August. Unidentified gunmen killed four mourners in Tongov.

On August 16th and 17th, militiamen (accused of being members of the Ebom community, and coded as such) attacked the Usumotong clan at an unspecified location in Abi . Soldiers repelled the attackers on both occasions. There are no reports of casualties or fatalities.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On August 18th, Boko Haram militants attacked Buni (Yobe state), injuring two villagers, and torching several buildings.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On August 18th, IS-affiliated Boko Haram forces attacked soldiers at Mogula (Borno state), killing four, and stealing two anti-aircraft guns.
On August 18th, an unknown group attacked the home of the Khana LG chairman (event coded at Bori, Rivers state, at geoprec2), torching his house.
On August 18th, Hausa and Yoruba vendors clashed in disputed circumstances in Oke-Odo (Lagos), causing a number of injuries (four serious). Police intervened to separate the groups. [size=large]

On August 18th, unknown gunmen killed a senior secondary school teachers union leader in Ngoksar village and a second civilian who was fleeing the attack at the nearby area of Tangu (Plateau state, coordinates for Tangu used at prec2).

On August 18th, Fulani pastoralists killed an armed bandit (coded as UAG) at Kango village in the area of Dan Sadau (Zamfara state, coordinates used at prec2). They brought the bandit's rifle to the governor as proof of their commitment to the peace process.

On August 17th or 18th, Fulani pastoralists were reported to have raided Araro (Oyo state), injuring seven civilians with machete attacks, whilst destroying farms and stealing money. Note that local police - whilst acknowledging skirmishes in the area - have denied that seven people were injured by machetes, although local doctors have supported the claims that at least three people were wounded by bladed weapons.

On August 18th, an armed group attacked Tsayau village (Katsina state, coordinates for Jibia used at prec2), looting a number of cattle. Villagers mobilised to pursue the raiders, and four villagers were killed in the firefight.

On August 19th, three people were killed by an unknown group at an unspecified area in Oyigbo local govt area (Rivers state, coordinates for Obigbo used at prec2), amidst an apparent spate of killings in the area.
On August 20th, retired police officers protested in Ilorin (Kwara state), at the partial payment of their pensions. [size=no report]

On August 20th, Economic and Financial Crimes Commission officers raided a property belonging to former Lagos governor Akinwunmi Ambode in Epe (Lagos). Youth - alleged to be in league with the governor - attacked the officers, damaging a car and injuring three officers. [size=no report]

On August 20th, unknown gunmen attacked the convoy of the deputy governor of Nasarawa state near Akwanga (Nasarawa state), killing three police and a civilian driver. The deputy governor was unharmed.

On August 21st, Fulani pastoralists attacked the village of Vat in Foron district (Plateau state, coordinates for Foron used at prec2), burning several houses. It is unclear whether there are casualties.
On August 21st, a pregnant Igbo lady was killed by suspected Fulani pastoralists at or near Emene (Enugu state).

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On August 21st, Boko Haram fighters (indicated by one source has having an IS affiliation) attacked Gubio (Borno state), prompting the army and CJTF presence to flee. One CJTF was abducted in the attack. Upon seizing control of the town, various public and domestic buildings were destroyed.

column7: Civilian JTF: Civilian Joint Task Force

Elements of the protesters threatened to escalate violent activities in the Delta unless payments were completed within two weeks. [size=no report]
On or before August 22nd, a member of the Sokoto assembly was abducted in Bodai (Sokoto state, coordinates for Boda used at prec2) by unknown gunmen.

On August 22nd, unknown gunmen (accused of being cultists) attacked two locations in the area of Khana (Rivers state, coordinates for Bori used at prec2), killing six (one of whom died of their injuries after the attack), and injuring an unspecified number. A school and the house of a professor were also torched.

On August 22nd, members of the PDP demonstrated outside the Oyo state assembly at Ibadan (Oyo state), in opposition to the appointment of a youthful APC member as Minister for Youth and Sports. [size=small]

After the local militias was defeated by the unidentified gunmen that were occasionally attacking the people in various villages of Kaduna state, the unidentified gunmen (that the villagers call as Bandits) attacked the civilians in sixteen villages, causing the displacement of 2000 people. Tura, Unguwan Gebi, Unguwan Dangauta, Unguwan Nayawu, Sabon Gida, Unguwan Alhaji Ahmadu, Kusau, Unguwan Pati, Unguwan Tofa, Sauran Giwa, Unguwan Makeri, Gigane, Dallatu, Sabon Gari, Gidan Sarkin Noma were the villages known to have been attacked. One event coded for the each found village and one event coded in Kaduna state center with GP3 for the unfound villages. Seven events in total. Five civilians were killed in the attacks, dispersed across seven events (1).

On 23 October 2020, a mob of several thousand rioters looted a government food warehouse in Osu town (Atakumosa West, Osun), after claiming that the stock had been locked up, instead of being distributed to the community. [size=several thousand]

On 23 October 2020, about 500 suspected members of the proscribed Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB) invaded the Oyigbo Area Command, Oyigbo and Afam Police Stations, setting them ablaze and damaging about fifteen vehicles APC (Port-Harcourt, Rivers). Two people were also killed.

Around 23 October 2020, #EndSARS demonstrators clashed with police operatives at Ogidi Police Station in Ogidi (Idemili North LGA, Anambra) over the death of two demonstrators when they attempted to burn the police station. Rioters beheaded a policeman in retaliation and burned the Council Headquarters and the High Court in Ogidi. [size=no report]
On 24 October 2020, a Niger communal militia invaded Hayin Beri village (Mariga LGA ,Niger) but were repelled by police operatives and local militiamen. One reported fatality.

On 24 October 2020, rioters looted the house of a former APC senate leader and set it ablaze in Calabar town (Calabar-Municipal, Cross River). The reason behind the rioting was not reported. [size=no report]
On 24 October 2020, local residents looted a government food and coronavirus palliatives warehouse in Kaduna town (Kaduna North, Kaduna). [size=no report]
On 24 October 2020, suspected ISWAP gunmen attacked a military base in Beddegana town (Tarmua, Yobe). One police officer and six militants were killed.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Around 24 October 2020 (as reported), Boko Haram militants ambushed the Nigerian army on the road between Gubio and Magumeri town (Magumeri, Borno). At least seven soldiers were killed and others injured. Militants also seized weapons and ammunition.
On 24 October 2020, security operatives opened fire on residents looting a coronavirus palliatives warehouse in Benin city (Oredo, Edo). One girl was shot and wounded. [size=no report]
Around 24 October 2020 (as reported), ISWAP attacked a Nigerian military base in Mallam Fatori (Abadam LGA, Borno), allegedly killing five soldiers.
On 24 October 2020, several thousand people ransacked and looted a government food warehouse in Jos town (Jos North, Plateau). [size=several thousand]

The rising cost of food and other necessities spark a protest in front of a government building, brandishing placards reading, ""We cant take it anymore, everything is expensive"" and ""Our families eat only one meal a day""

Thousands gather, including representatives of seven opposition political parties, to call for the Prime Minister, Carlos Gomes Junior, to resign his position due to his failing to curb the rising cost of goods.

15,000 gather for the second protest in five days to call for the resignation of Prime Minister Carlos Gomes Junior of the African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde, a party that had been in political power since Independence.
Thousands took to the streets of Bissau Friday for the third rally in three weeks to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Carlos Gomes Junior, who is accused of hindering an assassination probe.

Believing a pay protest by members of the military is an attempted coup against the Prime Minister one soldier is shot and a Naval Admiral is detained, believing he is the mastermind. A cache of weapons was seized by rouge soldiers.

Military personnel erected roadblocks through major thoroughfares to protest their pay and demand an increase. Included of the blocked roads was a street leading to the home and office of the Prime Minister, leading many to believe these actions were a coup attempt.
Security forces arrest and detain 25 rouge soldiers believed to be involved in a protest or coup.

Guinea-Bissaus ex-military intelligence deputy chief was shot dead by men in military uniform in the capital hours after polls closed in a presidential vote. No clear motive known. Guinea-Bissau military officials have denied the army was involved in the assassination.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Guinea-Bissau (2009-2012)
column17: Non-violent activity: Following a coup, Guinea-Bissau military orders Angolan troops ordered out of country.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Guinea-Bissau (2009-2012)
column17: Guinea-Bissau soldiers on Thursday night attacked the residence of outgoing premier and presidential hopeful Carlos Gomes Junior. ""It was attacked with rocket-propelled grenades and we were forced to retreat,"" said a police officer who had guarded the building. The coup military forces have taken control of the capital and a local radio station. The PM was detained and taken to an army barracks.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Guinea-Bissau (2009-2012)
column17: Coup forces violently disperse protesters who were demanding the immediate release of PM Carlos Gomes Jar and Acting President Raimundo Pereira, both believed detained in the wake of the 12 April coup d'etat.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Guinea-Bissau (2009-2012)
column17: Non-violent activity: Guinea-Bissaus new ruling junta banned marches Tuesday and warned it would crack down on demonstrators as the African Union suspended the country over last weeks military coup.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Guinea-Bissau (2009-2012)
column17: Non-violent activity: Coup forces officially dissolve the former government and declare a two year transition period for a civilian government. In the days the followed the junta backpedaled on their pledge for a two year transition period, giving the impression the period would be longer.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Guinea-Bissau (2009-2012)
column17: Non-violent activity: Guinea-Bissaus military junta says it has handed back power to civilians, six weeks after staging a coup that derailed presidential elections.
Non-violent activity: Angolan forces begin to remove troops and supplies from Guinea-Bissau following their presence in the country to province stable governance after a coup.
Civil Rights groups protest the execution of Gambian prisoners at the countries embassy.

column7: SYNAPROF: National Union of Teachers of Guinea Bissau
column17: The national union of teachers of Guinea-Bissau (SINAPROF) extended their 30 day strikes to 60 days and are willing to continue for 90 days if the government continues to ignore their legal rights and demands for back pay.

Exiled commando Captain Pansau Ntchama led an attack on the Para-Commando barracks (military base) in a failed coup attempt against the military junta that seized control in a coup last April. Six were killed. In response to accusations it was involved, Portugal replied that Ntchama ""never had the status of political asylum in Portugal""

Property destruction: Armed men invaded the head office of the African Party for the Independence of Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde (PAIGC) this morning and destroyed election posters of former PM Carlos Gomes Jr (from the interrupted March elections) following a failed coup attempt yesterday.

column9: Frenagolpe; PST: Solidarity and Labour Party
column17: Iancuba Indjai, leader of of Frenagolpe (Front Against Coup dEtat) and the Partido da Solidaridade e Trabalho (Solidarity and Labour Party - PST) was arrested, beaten by soldiers, some in plainclothes, and dumped 40 km outside of Bissau in critical condition.

Silvestre Alves, president of MDG: Movimento Democratico Guineense (Guinean Democratic Movement party) and critic of the transitional government was arrested by soldiers, beaten, and dumped with two broken legs and head injuries north of Bissau

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Guinea-Bissau (2009-2012)
column17: Arrests: Leader of the October 21 coup attempt Captain Pansau Ntchama is arrested, implicates ex-army chief of staff L. Gen. Zamora Induta in the attack.

Ocante Luis da Silva, an ally of the ex-army head Jose Zamora Induta and an official with Guine-Telecom was abducted from his home by a group of uniformed men on 6 Nov, his body was dropped off at the Simao Mendes National Hospital two days later and his death was announced 9 Nov
A group of soldiers accused of an attack on an elite commando barracks which the Guinea Bissau government described as an attempted coup (conducted in October 2012) appeared before a court martial.

Arrests: A Dutch businessman has been arrested in Guinea-Bissau for allegedly circulating ""false information"" about a potential coup, the countries army chief said. The suspect, who is also an honorary consul for Britain in Bissau, was arrested at his home by soldiers.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Agreement: Nine bomb disposal experts kidnapped by separatist rebels in Senegal in May were released on Friday in neighbouring Guinea-Bissau. It is unknown if a ransom was paid.
3 Nigerian embassy workers were killed by rioters.
Rioters stormed the Nigerian embassy due to child abduction allegtions. Police intervened and threw teargas.
Orlando Viegas, the state minister in charge of transport and telecommunications, was assaulted in this home by an unidentified group.
Non-violent activity: During registration for presidential elections, political parties had armed militias at registration sites.

column9: PAIGC: African Party for the Independence of Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde
column17: 15 PAIGC supporters were targeted by armed groups ahead of elections.

column9: PAIGC: African Party for the Independence of Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde
column17: Reports of 3 PAIGC supporters attacked by armed men attempting to influence the outcome of the elections.

column6: UNIOGBIS: United Nations Integrated Peacebuilding Office in Guinea-Bissau (2009-)
column17: Movement of forces: The Security Council extended the UN Integrated Peacebuilding Office in Guinea-Bissau, known as UNIOGBIS, until 30 November 2014, so that it can continue to assist in tackling a range of political challenges, many relatedto the current presidential elections.

19 killed instantly and 3 later died from injuries when a minibus crossed a landmine and exploded. The bus was traveling on route 70 between Bissora and Encheia when it swerved off the road to avoid water and hit a mine and exploded near Mansoa (60km from capital). Mine is believed to be left by the Portuguese colonial army during war of independence 40 years ago.
President Jose Mario Vaz pardoned six soldiers convicted of a 2012 coup attempt on army barracks, led by ex-army orfficer Pansau Ntchama. Announced made via radio.

Police officers beat a man to death while in police custody in Bissora, Oio region, in July 2015. Four police officers were convicted in May 2016 in connection with the event, including three who were sentenced to seven years and three months' imprisonment and one to five years' imprisonment.

Guineans protested against their Ambassys indifference toward crimes and assassinations targeting them in the country. Several people have been arrested including the leaders of the Guinea community in Guinea Bissau and of the Haali Poular. The latter were freed on 30 September.

column7: PAIGC: African Party for the Independence of Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde
column17: Hundreds of supporters of the ruling African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde (PAIGC) threw rocks and burnt tyres near the presidential palace in the capital to protest against the presidents naming of a new prime minister, which they deemed unconstitutional. Police forces attempted to disperse the demonstrators with tear gas.
Police in Bissau used tear gas to disperse hundreds of protesters calling for parliament to be dissolved and new elections to be held.
Protest by civil society groups in Bissau over President Vazs inability to resolve the political deadlock in the country.

Hundreds of people marched through the capital demanding the departure of President Jose Mario Vaz, a day after parliament rejected a programme submitted by his Prime Minister. PAIGC announced that they voted against the programme of the PM because his government is illegitimate.
Government members and supporters of president Vaz marched in Bissau to call for the resumption of activities of the Parliament.
Hundreds of protesters marched in the capital to demand the departure of President Jose Mario Vaz following an 18-month-long political crisis.
Thousands of protesters in the capital demanded President Jose Mario Vaz step down to resolve the prolonged political crisis in the country.

column7: VNCCM: Vigilant Non-Compliant Citizens Movement; PAIGC: African Party for the Independence of Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde
column17: Members of a civil society group, the Vigilant Non-Compliant Citizen's Movement, as well as PAIGC members, were badly beaten by police during a protest march in Bissau criticising president Vaz.

Unknown assailants attacked the leader of a civil society group close to PAIGC critical of president Vaz, the Vigilant Non-Compliant Citizen's Movement, at his home in Bissau, leaving him severely injured.
International media have reported that hundreds of protesters marched in Guinea Bissau over the weekend to demand the departure of President Jose Mario Vaz.

column7: PAIGC: African Party for the Independence of Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde
column17: Police used tear gas to disperse a protest by around 2,000 people demanding that President Jose Mario Vaz resign.
Clashes between government party supporters and the supporters of 15 dissidents MPs were reported: 4 wounded.
Opposition suppoters went to the streets to ask for government's resignation

column7: PAIGC: African Party for the Independence of Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde; APU: United People's Alliance Party
column17: Security forces dispersed with grenades, a march organized in Bissau by a group of 18 opposition political parties, while the demonstrators were a few meters from the Presidential Palace. The repression of the march that has gathered thousands of people, has made at least nine wounded, including three serious, according to the organizers.

column7: PAIGC: African Party for the Independence of Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde; APU: United People's Alliance Party
column17: 17 November. A day after the protest was violently dispersed by police forces, opposition demonstrated again in Bissau. This time peaceful without incidents of violence

Thousands of Bissau-Guinean citizens and foreigners lit candles on Thursday in front of the Libyan Embassy in Bissau to demand respect for human rights and the end of the practice of slavery of Africans in Libya.
The police dispersed with teargas a march organized by the Collective of 18 political parties opposed to the current regime of President Jose Mario Vaz

column8: Mutiny of Military Forces of Guinea-Bissau (2014-)
column17: Arrests: Six soldiers were arrested for conspiracy to kill Guinea-Bissau's Chief of Staff General Biague Na Ntam

16 December. Four members of the Armed Forces were arrested for being involved in a plot to attack the Chief of General Staff of the Armed Forces General Na N'Tam. Further arrests on 23 and 26 December
Thousands of president Vaz supporters demonstrated against CEDEAO's sanctions.

04 or 05 March. Some activists of the Movement of Conscientious and Non-Conformist Citizens demonstrated in support of the ECOWAS sanctions and handed in a petition requesting that President Vaz should be added to the sanctions list

column7: UNTG: National Union of Workers of Guinea Bissau
column17: On 11 July, hundreds of civil servants took to the streets of Bissau to demand a rise in the minimum wage and better living conditions.
On Oct 21, protesters demonstrated in Bissau against ""lack of transparency"" in the electoral census in the run-up to legislative elections on November 18th.
On November 23, thousands of students protested on the streets of Bissau demanding the reopening of the public schools.
On November 25, students settled a camp in front of the Education Ministry in Bissau to protest against the educational strike and demand the return of the classes. Thy camped until November 30th.
On December 1, civilians took the streets of Bissau to protest against violence against women and children.
On December 7, students took the streets of Bissau to protest against the educational strike and demand the return of the classes.

column7: MCCI: Movement of Conscious and Dissatisfied Citizens
column17: On December 15, in Bissau, the Movement of Conscious and Unhappy Citizens took the streets to protest demanding the immediate schedule of national elections by the national government.
On May 1st, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, a march was held in Bissau to demand better working conditions and an increase of salaries. [Size=not reported]

On Feb 8th, students in Guinea- Bissau carried out a violent protest over an impending strike action by teachers. Demonstrators blocked roads, burned tires and vehicles, looted shops and headquarters of the ruling party and a minister's residence. Police used warning shots to disperse the protesters. No fatalities have been reported.
On Sept 5th, demonstrators marched in Bissau to protest against the correction of the electoral register, ahead of presidential elections to be held on Nov 24th. [Size=hundreds]
On May 22nd, civilians held a peaceful protest to demand the country's President to appoint the Prime Minister, a government and schedule presidential elections. [Size=thousands]
On May 25th, civilians held a protest in Bissau demanding the appointment of the prime minister and formation of the Guinean government. [Size=thousands]
On May 27th, school students protested against professors' strikes. Guinean Police intervened to disperse the crowd. [Size=hundreds]
On June 6th, opposition parties marched to ask the President not to give in to pressure to appoint a new government. [Size=no report]

column7: UNTG: National Union of Workers of Guinea Bissau
column17: On June 6th, the National Union of Workers of Guinea (UNTG) and the General Confederation of Independent Trade Unions (CGSI) held a protest to demand he conclusion of the approval process of the new Labour Code, and an increase in the minimum wage to 150 euros per month. [Size=no report]

column7: PRS: Social Renewal Party; APU: United People's Alliance Party
column17: On Oct 26th 2019, in Bissau, police forces fired tear gas on a non-authorized protest organized by the Social Renewal Party and the United People's Alliance Party. Demonstrators protested over the way elections to be held on Nov 24th are being organized. [size=no report]

On Oct 26th 2019, in Bissau, a demonstration was held to demand a delay in presidential elections to prevent voter fraud. Police intervened firing teargas and beating protesters. One protester was killed, many injured.
On Nov 6 2019, Aristides Gomes held a Council of Ministers at the government palace whose access was blocked by the National Guard in Bissau (Sector Autonomo de Bissau, Bissau).

column6: ECOWAS: Economic Community Of West African States
column17: On Nov 8 2019, the ECOWAS decided to send additional troops in Guinea Bissau, in the light of elections to be held on Nov 24.

On 28 February 2020, Cipriano Cassama was voted interim president by lawmakers. They maintained that the election of Umaro Sissoco Embalo which took place two days before was not legal. This turned Guinea-Bissau into a nation with two presidents.

On 1 March 2020, Cipriano Cassama resigned in Bissau (Sector Autonomo de Bissau, Bissau), after serving one day as the Guinea-Bissau's interim president, claiming that his personal life and the stability of the country were threatened.
On 5 March 2020, military forces stormed the residence of the Minister of Territorial Administration, Odete Semedo in Bissau (Sector Autonomo de Bissau, Bissau).

On 18 March 2020, the Government of Nuno Nabian announced the suspension of masses and all activities, involving crowds of people, as a way to prevent the pandemic of the new coronavirus. Borders were also closed and the capital's airport banned for landings.

On 26 March 2020, the Guinean Ministry of Interior imposed a series of social confinement measures, aiming at limiting the circulation of people and vehicles on public roads as a way to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Circulation for purchases and sales of essential products is allowed between 07:00 and 11:00 in the morning.
On 28 March 2020, the President Sissoco Embalo implemented a state of emergency in Guinea Bissau as a measure to face the coronavirus pandemic. The measure is valid until April 11.
On 8 April 2020, police officers beat four young people in Bissau city, allegedly for being involved in drug use.

On 7 May 2020, police forces occupied the parliament in Bissau (Sector Autonomo de Bissau, Bissau) to prevent the entry of deputies, officials and other people. Their aim was reportedly to impede the holding of a press conference by members of the African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde (PAIGC). No violence reported
On 14 May 2020, an armed clash over land ownership between villagers from Reino de Bijimita and Cufongo communities erupted in Quinhamel (Quinhamel, Biombo). Two fatalities reported.

On 23 May 2020, an armed confrontation between people from Elia and Arame communities took place in Susana (Sao Domingos, Cacheu). The clash, which erupted because of a land dispute, resulted in one death, one missing person and seven injured.

On 20 July 2020, doctors, nurses and other employees of the Raoul Follearau Hospital gathered in front of the institution in Bissau (Sector Autonomo de Bissau) to demand better work conditions. [size=no report]

column16: Agencia de Noticias da Guine; RTP; Deutsche Welle; O Democrata; All Africa; Twitter; Jornal no Pintcha
column17: On 26 July 2020, the office of the Radio Capital FM was destroyed by a group of armed individuals in Bissau (Sector Autonomo de Bissau). The event was largely reported and several institutions condemned the attack to the press.
On 27 July 2020, a group gathered in front of the Portuguese Embassy in Bissau (Sector Autonomo de Bissau) to pay homage to a national killed in Portugal in a racism related attack. [size=no report]

On 5 August 2020, a group demonstrated in front of the Portuguese Embassy in Bissau (Sector Autonomo de Bissau, Bissau) against racism, and to pay homage to a national killed in Portugal on 25 July 2020. [size=no report]

On 6 August 2020, a group of journalists demonstrated in front of the Radio Capital FM building in Bissau (Sector Autonomo de Bissau) to condemn the destruction of the radio's office last week and to demand justice. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Guinea-Bissau (2014-) National Guard
column17: Around 21 August 2020 (as reported), agents of the National Force beat and injured some women and the chief of the Madina Atche village, Buba sector (Quinara). According to a resident, the chief was tortured, and the agents arrested some individuals.

On 7 September 2020, students of the Attadamun school center gathered in front of the school in Bissau (Setor Autonomo de Bissau) during a demonstration against the extraordinary exams cancellation (supposed to begin on 7 September). The cancellation was related to teachers demanding the payment of half of 3 months of allowances. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, students of the Attadamun school center gathered in front of the school in Bissau (Setor Autonomo de Bissau) for a second day during a demonstration against the extraordinary exams cancellation (supposed to begin on 7 September). The group invaded the residency of the center director. Officers of the Public Order police and Rapid Intervention were called. 4 students were arrested. [size=at least 4]

column16: Liga Guineense dos Direitos Humanos; RTP
column17: On 11 September 2020, a woman was killed with sticks and machetes blows by a group in Ndaliel village near Buba (Buba, Quinara) over witchcraft accusations. After killing her, the group also cut essential organs. 4 individuals were arrested. [size=at least 4]

column16: DW; O Democrata; Agencia de Noticias da Guine
column17: On 5 October 2020, 2 activists linked to the MADEM-G15 were taken and beaten by a group of 5 to 8 non-uniformed men in Bissau (Setor Autonomo de Bissau, Bissau). The 2 were released the next day from the second squadron police station, without explanation. The group are accused of being part of the security of the President of the Republic.

column17: DRC military forces fire across border into Rwanda and kills two civilians
Movement of forces: Rwandan forces and M23 stage advance on Goma via Gisyeni in Rwanda

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FDLR forces attack locations in Western province of Rwanda; 12 rebels killed in two battles

column17: FDLR forces attack locations in Western province of Rwanda; 12 rebels killed in two battles

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FDLR attack civilians and abduct several during incursion into Rwandan territory; one civilian killed

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column7: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: FDLR forces attack locations in Western province of Rwanda

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: FDLR rebels attack civilians inside Volcano National Park; park warden killed and several injured
Protests in Kigali after genocide acquittals by UN tribunal
Agreement: M23 rebels flee into Rwanda; DRC claims that Ntaganda is among them. Rwanda denies, states he is still in DRC. Rwandan forces disarm rebels that entered the country
Allies of opposition leader gather to stage demonstration outside court; police arrest demonstrators
Grenade thrown by unknown group kills one and injures eight
Unknown group throws grenade into families home; several injured

11 people claiming ties with the Catholic Church were arrested over holding illegal assembly in the City of Kigali. The group, under Intwarane za Yezu na Mariya, will be charged with illegal demonstration and public gathering, inciting insurrection and trouble among the population, according to Police. Members of the group, were arrested while drumming and sounding other instruments in Kiyovu, allegedly, en route to the State House.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: The UN Stabilisation Mission in the Congo (Monusco) has been accused by Rwanda of deliberately firing two mortar bombs into Gasiza and Kageshi cells, Rwanda, from areas it controls together with the Congolese army, FARDC. Monusco denies this.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column7: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: The UN Stabilisation Mission in the Congo (Monusco) has been accused by Rwanda of deliberately firing two mortar bombs into Gasiza and Kageshi cells, Rwanda, from areas it controls together with the Congolese army, FARDC. Monusco denies this.
A grenade attack at Ubumwe Village near Nyabugogo abattoir killed 3 people and injured 32. Three people have been arrested.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: The government has requested the Expanded Joint Verification Mechanism (EJVM) to visit Rubavu to verify effects of a rocket bomb that landed in the district from a Congolese area controlled by FARDC. According to the Rwanda Defence Force (RDF), a 107mm rocket landed in an urban area of Bugu Cell in Cyanzarwe Sector at around 1pm yesterday and caused damage to property.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Five bombs were shot on 24 August from the DRCongo to various parts of Cyanzarwe and Busasamana areas of the Rubavu District, Western Province. Except some crops that were destroyed, nobody was reported to have been injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Five bombs were shot on 24 August from the DRCongo to various parts of Cyanzarwe and Busasamana areas of the Rubavu District, Western Province. Except some crops that were destroyed, nobody was reported to have been injured.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A rocket landed near a market in Mbugangari cell, Gisenyi sector where a woman was killed and the six-month-old baby she was carrying on her back was seriously injured by shrapnel.

Ten former M23 rebels were arrested on Monday for inciting violence at Cyasemakamba Refugee Camp. They refused to comply with a standard security search by police. They were reported to have attacked the police, who shot in the air to calm the situation.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: A grenade exploded at a market in Kigali on Friday evening. One person was killed. The FDLR are believed to be behind the attack.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: A second grenade exploded at a market in Kigali on Saturday evening. One person was killed. The FDLR are believed to be behind the attack.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: DR Congolese troops fired three bombs and small arms across the border into Rubavu, injuring a civilian.
Early last month, unidentified assailants shot dead a police officer in Muhoza sector in Musanze
Teachers union protests the firing of seven teachers at an APEC-run school in Nyamirambo
1-year old girl killed and two others injured in grenade blast in the home of the mayor of Musanze District
Six people were injured when unidentified armed men on a motorcycle threw a grenade at people near a bus stop; they are believed to be anti-government rebels
Agreement: Rwandan government rejected a request by the FDLR Hutu rebels for negotiations after they announced a unilateral end to hostilities

column8: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
column17: Agreement: 8 FDRL and 1 Mayi-Mayi fighter were handed over by MONUSCO to Rwanda for repatriation

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column16: AFP; Rwanda Focus; New Times (Rwanda); News of Rwanda
column17: A section of the DRC army crossed into Rwanda and opened fire on RDF troops. These troops retaliated, killing one soldier. Other sources claim that Rwandan troops crossed into DRC and abducted one soldier, killing him later. In later clashes, four more DRC soldiers were killed

Hundreds of angry students protested on the streets of Kigali, shouting anti-BBC slogans. The protesters marched to the Parliament buildings and handed a petition demanding readdress for the BBC documentary ""Rwandas Untold Story"" and then marched to the BBC offices in Kigali. Two student groups, AERG and FAGER organied the protest.
Thousands of students in Rwanda took to the streets to protest the BBC documentary ""Rwandas Untold Story"" which they say trivializes the Rwandan Genocide.
Protests occurred across Eastern Province this weekend against the BBC documentary, Rwandas Untold Story. The protests were mostly carried out by women, youth and disabled people.
Thousands march against gender-based violence as part of the global 16 Days of Activism camapaign.
A father and son accused of theft were killed in a alleged mob justice attack after their bodies were found in a field at a banana plantation.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A Rwandan military spokesman has said that FARDC forces fired a rocket onto their territory near Rubavu.
A Tutsi genocide survivor was found murdered by an unknown assailant in the lead up to the national genocide memorial week in April.
A Tutsi genocide survivor was found murdered by an unknown assailant in the lead up to the national genocide memorial week in April.
The former personal doctor of President Paul Kagame was shot while in detention at a Kigali police station, allegedly as an act of self-defense. He died in hospital of his wounds.
During the Genocide Memorial week, Hutu groups demolished the home of a Tutsi genocide survivor and set fire to another surivors barn. 17 people were arrested.
Hundreds from the Northern Province ""stormed"" parliament seeking the amendment of the Constitution to allow President Kagame to run for a third term.
Over 500 employees of Modern Terrace Construction protested against delays in the payment of their wages.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karenzi Karake in London, clogging roads in Kigali.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karenzi Karake in London, clogging roads in Kigali.
Thousands protested against the recent arrest of General Karenzi Karake in London.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Thousands of protesters in the Southern Province marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Thousands of protesters in the Southern Province marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Thousands protested against the recent arrest of General Karenzi Karake in London.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Thousands of protesters in the Eastern Province marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Thousands of protesters in the Southern Province marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Thousands of protesters in the Eastern Province marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Thousands of protesters in the Eastern Province marched against the recent arrest of General Karake in London.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karenzi Karake in London, clogging roads in Kigali.
Protesters marched against the recent arrest of General Karenzi Karake in London, clogging roads in Kigali.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Burundi (2005-)
column17: Burundi has claimed that rebels have set up military training camps in Rwanda and that the generals who attempted to stage a coup on May 13 are being harboured in that country. UN reports confirmed Rwandan military trained civilians from Burundi in military tactics.
Over 30 workers of the newly-constructed Mt. Kenya University in Kicukiro district of Kigali engaged in a sit-in protest to demand payment of their wages.
Youth in Gisenyi marched in collaboration with their counterparts in Goma (DRC) to celebrate world peace day.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: On Lake Kivu between Kamembe in Rwanda and Bukavu in DRC, Congolese forces shot at Rwandan forces, killing a military captain and injuring two noncommissioned officers. The incident occurred as Rwandan forces were investigating the arrests of Rwandan fisherman by the FARDC. The fishermen remain in the custody of FARDC.
Arrests: The vice president of the opposition party FDU, Boniface Twagirimana, was arrested for unspecified charges.

column6: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: FDLR based in DRC attacked a police station and were pushed back by national security forces.
Security Measures: Government expelled more than 800 Burundians between May 13 - 15.

More than 500 students staged a protest over teacher resignations, throwing stones at the school. Police fired shots in the air to disperse the crowd and later arrested three teachers for allegedly inciting the protests.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Rwandan soldiers found a DRC soldier on their soil and allegedly shot and decapitated him before throwing his body back into DRC. DRC soldier reportedly threw the body back into Rwanda.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: DRC soldier found on Rwandan soil was shot and killed by troops after he failed to stop as ordered.
Police killed Islamist militant in a three hour shoot-out.
Police attempted to arrest suspected Islamic militants, and when they ""turned violent"" they shot and killed three. Three others arrested.
A Rwandan patrol intercepted a group of Burundian vendors in Rwanda and opened fire, killing 2.
In Rusizi District, Bugarama Sector, Ryankana cell, Kabuga village, unidentified armed group attacked and killed two civilians and wounded one.
Inmates at Gasabo Prison staged a demonstration, rioting and throwing stones at nearby houses. The police were brought in and used teargas to quell the protesters.
A member of the banned opposition party, FDU, was found murdered. Members of the party believe it was a political assassination.

An unidentified armed group from Burundi attacked a bistro in Ryankana, near the Burundian border. 1 person was killed and 8 people were wounded. The group then fled across the border back to Burundi.
29 August. A Rwandan woman and here family were arrested and forcibly disappeared by police forces in Kigali, Nyarugenge.
The Rwandan police invaded the home of Rwigara, an opposition politician who had attempted to run against Kagame in the election. They arrested her and took her to an unknown location.
Arrests: Rwandan police arrested an opposition leader, Rwigara, and her mother and sister.
Rwandan police are believed to have killed a Burundian national and thrown his body into the Kanyaru river. The refugee was apparently refusing to enter the Burundian refugee camp.

column6: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: A DRC military patrol attacked a Rwandan military position near Iterambere village, in Musanze. The Rwandan force retaliated, killing 3 DRC soldiers.

Congolese refugees in the Karongi Refugee Camp held a two-day sit-in outside the UN offices in Kiziba/Karongi refugee camp. They are angry about a recent reduction in food assistance and are demanding resettlement.

Rwandan police and military opened fire on a group of Congolese refugees protesting outside the UN offices in Kiziba/Karongi Refugee Camp. 11 refugees were killed in the gunfire and another 20 were injured. 7 police officers were injured by the crowd. 15 refugees have been arrested for staging illegal demonstrations.
Arrests: On 28 March, 33 Burundian refugees, belonging to a Catholic sect, were arrested in the Gashora site in Bugesera, Rwanda for allegedly ""instigating violence"" during a registration exercise.

A lawyer disappeared in early April. His death in the Ndera police station was announced 23 April by the Rwandan police. The coordinator of the Observatory of Human Rights at Rwanda highlighted contradictions in police statements, suggesting police involvement.
On 10 April, a grenade was placed at the entrance of the house of a survivor of the 1994 genocide in Nyakabungo village, Karama cell of Ntongwe sector. He is the security chief of the village.
On 1 May, 23 Congolese refugees from Kiziba refugee camp were arrested for throwing stones and attacking police officers. One refugee was reported killed by UNHCR.

Mass grave: On the week of 7-13 May, six new mass graves from the genocide were found in Ndera Sector, Gasabo District of Rwanda. They were found in the compound of the neuro-psychiatric hospital where about 80,000 Tutsi had fled expecting to get refuge. 366 remains were exhumed from one of the six graves.
On 3 June, hundreds of Rwandans marched in Kigali to encourage the public to address plastic pollution. The march was organised by the Ministry of Environment.

On 19 June, an armed group shot five people and killed two in a village in Nyabimata Cell, Nyaruguru district, Southern Province. The assailants came from the Nyungwe forest which borders Burundi and fled in the same direction after the attack.

On 19 June 2018, attackers (alleged to be from the FLN, and coded as such) crossed from Burundi into Rwanda and attacked Nyabimata (Southern Province), killing two civilians and wounding three. One source suggests a local government executive was abducted (another source says he was merely injured).

23 June, on or around. An attack was reported in Nyaruguru district, Rwanda, killing two people and injuring three. An administrative authority was kidnapped. Burundians are suspected of being accomplices.

Non-violent activity: on 23 June, at least 280 Burundians living in Rwanda were expelled for reasons still unclear. Some believe it is because Burundians are suspected of being involved in an attack in Nyaruguru district.

On 1 July, a newly emerged rebel group, the National Liberation Forces, claimed responsibility for an attack on Nyaruguru District, Nyabimata Sector, Ruhinga cell, Cyamuzi village. The assailants fired gunshots in the air and looted property. IGIHE claimed that 2 people were killed. The Rwanda police says they also abducted some of the local people to help them carry their loot, but released them soon after when the security forces came to rescue the locals.

Arrests: on 18 July, several hundred undocumented Burundians were arrested in the Burma refugee camp in Mahama. Some sources indicate more than a thousand were arrested. The move came amidst tensions in Rwanda with armed groups suspected to come from Burundi.
22 September. Three mass graves of victims of the Rwnanda Genocide against the Tutsi were discovered In Rubavu District.
26 November. Thousands of protesters marched in Kigali against gender-based violence. The march was part of state-organized days against gender-based violence
05 December. Rwandan officials announced that further mass graves were found in Kabuga suburb of Kigali. The graves were dug in 1994 during the Genocide.

column8: FDLR: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
column17: 09 December. DRC-based FDLR rebels attacked a base of the Rwanda military forces in Cyamabuye. The attack was repulsed, four FDLR rebels killed and at least two RDF soldiers. An injured civilian was rushed to the hospital.

column7: MRCD: Rwanda Movement for Democratic Change
column17: On 10 December 2018, MRCD-Ubumwe FLN led by Paul Rusesabagina attacked civilians in the Nyungwe Forest (Rusizi, Western Province). 2 were killed and 8 injured, with vehicles burned.

On December 15th, an unidentified armed group attacked Cyitabi sector of Nyamagabe District (coordinates for the latter used at precision 2), killing two civilians (plus two who later died of their wounds), wounding eight, and abducting 74. UPDATE: the FLN rebel movement has subsequently declared responsibility for the attacks in the area, and the ensuing clashes with Rwandan soldiers.

On December 16th or 17th, RDF soldiers intercepted the unidentified armed group which had attacked Cyitabi sector on December 15th. The interception occurred in Nyamagabe, close to the border with Burundi. Three attackers were killed by the RDF according to a military press statement, and 74 civilians who had been abducted on Dec 15th were rescued. The army said the remaining attackers fled into Burundi. UPDATE: the FLN rebel movement has subsequently declared responsibility for the attacks in the area, and the ensuing clashes with Rwandan soldiers.

On Feb 27th, Rwandan authorities closed the border with Uganda at Gatuna (Northern Province), amidst turbulent relations between Kigali and Kampala. On March 5th, Rwanda authorities accused Uganda of supporting Ugandan rebel groups, and on March 8th, reports emerged of Rwandan security agents dismantling temporary bridges at certain crossings along the Rwanda-Uganda border.

On March 9th, the body of Anselme Mutuyimana - the spokesman for the FDU-Inkingi leader Victoire Ingabire - was discovered at an unspecified location close to Gishwati forest (Western Province). The deceased had been missing for three months and allegedly killed on the night of March 8-9th. As of 17th March reports indicate that a suspect has been arrested.

column9: MRCD: Rwanda Movement for Democratic Change
column17: On or before April 30th, the Rwandan Investigation Bureau arrested FLN rebel leader Major 'Sankara' Callixte Nsabimana at an undisclosed location in Rwanda (coordinates for Kigali used pending further information). The group has claimed responsibility for several attacks in late 2018, and is the armed wing of the MRCD political party.

On May 2nd, plain-clothes Rwandan soldiers shot and wounded a Rwandan businessman as he attempted to cross the border into Uganda with 11 of his Rwandan workers, carrying 500kg of beans. Two Rwandan soldiers intercepted the group from the Rwandan side of the border, and two from the Ugandan side. The event happened at Nyakabungo (Northern Province), and comes in the context of tensions between Uganda and Rwanda.

On July 9th, prisoners at Nyarugenge (Kigali) demonstrated against community services activities. Authorities reported a small number of protesters (who have subsequently been charged) were attempting to incite other prisoners. [size=28]
On July 22nd, police shot dead a suspect (who had been linked along with three others to a murder case of a local official) as he reportedly attempted to escape in Cyinzuzi (Northern province).
23 September. The FDU party coordinator Sylidio Dusabumuremyi was stabbed to death at his workplace in Shyogwe hospital by unidentified attackers.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy (Uranana Faction)
column16: Deutsche Welle; Daily Monitor (Uganda); Chimp Reports; New Times (Rwanda)
column17: On October 4th, an unknown group attacked Kinigi (Northern Province), killing 14 civilians and wounding 18. Authorities have subsequently announced that the group is a splinter faction of the FDLR which goes by the name of RUD-Uranana, which crossed over from the Congolese border. (Note: some initial reports suggested Rwanda security forces were among the dead and/or engaged in combat with the attackers; subsequent reports suggest this is not the case)

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy (Uranana Faction)
column17: On or around October 5th, Rwandan security forces (coded here as army) reportedly killed 19 members and arrested 5 members of the group responsible for the Oct 4th attack on Kinigi (which authorities have identified as a splinter faction of the FDLR named RUD-Uranana). Information about the event(s) is limited; one event coded at time prec2 and geoprec2, using Kinigi (Northern Province) as the location.
On October 19th, 2019, an unknown assailant threw a grenade at an unspecified location in Kamembe town (Western province), wounding four men. There is no clear motivation for the attack.

On November 4, 2019, two Rwadan civilians were shot and wounded by Rwandan security personnel (coded as army) as they attempted to cross back into Rwanda near the Katuna border post (coordinates for Gatuna, Northern Province, used at prec2). The victims were able to make it back to the Rwandan side of the border, and have received medical treatment.

On 7 and 8 November 2019, an unidentified armed group attacked Rwanda army positions on the Burundi-Rwanda border in the Kibira-Nyungwe forest (coordinates for Nyungwe Forest, Western Province, used at geoprec2). The Burundian attackers may be RED-TABARA and FRODEBU forces, although this is unconfirmed (actor1 coded as UAG). The sources make no mention of casualties.

On 7 and 8 November 2019, an unidentified armed group attacked Rwanda army positions on the Burundi-Rwanda border in the Kibira-Nyungwe forest (coordinates for Nyungwe Forest, Western Province, used at geoprec2). The Burundian attackers may be RED-TABARA and FRODEBU forces, although this is unconfirmed (actor1 coded as UAG). The sources make no mention of casualties.

08 November 2019. An unidentified armed group clashed with Rwanda military forces on the Burundi-Rwanda border in the Kibira-Nyungwe forest. Sources say the clash happened on the Rwanda side of the border. These are likely RED-TABARA and FRODEBU forces which have been fighting in Burundi. No fatalities reported in the clash.

On November 10, five Ugandan smugglers were intercepted by Rwandan police near Tabagwe (Eastern Province) along the border with Uganda. Police shot two smugglers dead, whilst the other three escaped across the border. Police claimed that they were attacked by the group, which has been disputed by the survivors.

On 14 November 2019, an unidentified armed group once again attacked Rwanda army positions on the Burundi-Rwanda border in the Kibira-Nyungwe forest (coordinates for Nyungwe Forest, Western Province, used at geoprec2). The Burundian attackers may be RED-TABARA and FRODEBU forces, although this is unconfirmed (actor1 coded as UAG). The sources make no mention of casualties.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy (Uranana Faction)
column17: On 3 and 4 December 2019, FDLR-RUD forces were alleged to have engaged in clashes in Kinigi sector (Northern Province, coordinates for Kinigi used at geoprec2) after crossing from the DRC, with unspecified Rwandan security forces (presumed to be army) killing ""many"" and capturing several rebels (3 fatalities coded pending further information). Rwandan authorities claimed that Uganda was involved in organising the violence.

column6: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy (Uranana Faction)
column17: On 3 and 4 December 2019, FDLR-RUD forces were alleged to have engaged in clashes in Kinigi sector (Northern Province, coordinates for Kinigi used at geoprec2) after crossing from the DRC, with unspecified Rwandan security forces (presumed to be army) killing ""many"" and capturing several rebels (3 fatalities coded pending further information). Rwandan authorities claimed that Uganda was involved in organising the violence.
On 6 January 2020, a mass grave was discovered at the airstrip at Rabavu (Western Province) dating back from the Rwandan genocide. As of 9 Jan, 141 bodies have been exhumed.

On or before 11 January 2020, Rwandan soldiers shot and killed two suspected smugglers at Rabavu (Western Province), having mistaken the two for rebels crossing from the DRC. The source notes there have been a large number of such killings in the area in 2017.
Between 12 and 30 March 2020, military forces beat up, injured and kidnapped several civilians in the Kangondo 2 and Kibiraro 1 neighborhoods of Kigali (Nyarugenge, Kigali City).

On 25 March 2020, police forces attacked and killed 2 civilians in Nyanza (Nyamagabe, Southern Province) for breaking the coronavirus confinement. Police deny this and said they acted in self-defense.
On or before 27 March 2020, a group of at least 4 carried out popular justice, killing an alleged banana thief in Rubavu district (Western Province). [size=at least 4]
As reported on 3 April 2020, 3 soldiers raped an unknown number of girls on coronavirus lockdown at the Banyehe school in Kigali (Nyarugenge, Kigali City).

On 8 April 2020, police forces arrested 6 journalists and placed them in Ramera Police Station in Kigali (Nyarugenge, Kigali City). Witnesses say they were arrested for exposing poor government policies related to coronavirus.
On 9 April 2020, a mass grave was found and exhumed in the Ruramira sector (Kayonza, Eastern Province), containing over 80 bodies from the genocide.

On 15 April 2020, refugees that had recently been transferred from Libya refugee camps demonstrated against living conditions due to coronavirus restrictions at the Gashora refugee camp outside Kigali (Nyarugenge, Kigali City). Police intervened to stop the demonstration. [size=no report]
On 7 May 2020, an unidentified armed group threw a grenade into a salon in Ndera (Gasabo, Kigali City). 1 person was killed and 11 were injured.
On 11 May 2020, an unidentified armed group of about 10 men attacked and killed a pastor in Muyumbu (Rwamagana, Eastern Province).
On 1 June 2020, police forces shot and killed a Ugandan trader in Sebeya village near Marembo (Burera, Northern Province). He was accused of smuggling goods into Rwanda.
Around 12 June 2020 (as reported), 2 soldiers attacked and injured some civilians and raped women in Rugarama village in Nyamata Sector (Bugesera, Eastern Province). The soldiers were arrested later.

On 26 June 2020, Rwandan military forces clashed with around 100 unidentified armed gunmen from Burundi near the Ruheru military position (Nyaruguru, Southern Province). 4 of the unidentified group, carrying official Burundian military equipment, were killed, 3 captured and others fled back to Gihisi, Burundi. 3 Rwandan soldiers were injured.
On 3 July 2020, Rwandan police shot and killed 2 Burundian refugees in Mahama (Kirehe, Eastern Province). Police accused the refugees of smuggling drugs.

Around 10 July 2020 (as reported), 3 bodies were discovered in Nemba (Bugesera, Eastern Province). Due to the bodies being found 5 meters inside the border of Rwanda, and there were signs of them having been dragged across the border from Burundi, it is believed the victims and attackers were Burundian. This comes during escalating political tension between the two countries.

column8: RED-TABARA: Resistance to the Rule of Law in Burundi
column17: On 29 September 2020, Rwandan military forces arrested 19 RED-TABARA near the Nyungwe Forest area of Nyaruguru (Southern Province). They had crossed over from Burundi into Rwanda.
People protest power cuts by burning tires in suburban Dakar.
People protest power cuts by burning tires in suburban Dakar.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: An army spokesman says that seven Senegalese soldiers have been killed in an attack in the countries southern Casamance region, where rebels have struggled for independence for decades. The following day the army sent several patrols in the area to try to capture the assailants.

Senegalese police armed with riot shields and batons on Wednesday prevented opposition supporters from holding a banned march to protest the squandering of public funds, an AFP journalist reported.The police awaited the protesters where the march was scheduled to start, and dozens who showed up were pushed back into adjacent streets.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Two soldiers of the Senegalese army were killed and another injured on Tuesday in the troubled southern region of Casamance during confrontations with armed men belonging to the separatist Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance (MFDC), a security source has revealed. The same source said the incident happened between 8 a.m. and 9 a.m. at the Silinkine village, which is not far away from the countries border with Gambia, when soldiers attempted to pursue people who had blocked a national road.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Fighting took place in the area of Basada on Thursday 13 January 2011. Eye witnesses, who spoke to this reporter during his visit to the border area between the Gambia and Senegal, said a Senegalese media reported that 3 solders have lost their lives in the fighting. However there were no reports of any deaths on the rebel side.
The anti-capitalist alternative to the World Economic Forum in Davos, the World Social Forum, has kicked off in Senegal with tens of thousands marching in the capital Dakar.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: The Senegalese army and separatist rebels in Casamance province fought for nearly five hours in a battle that left one soldier dead, an army officer said.
The Confederation of Autonomous Unions [CSA] yesterday staged a protest march to denounce what it calls the high cost of living and violations of workers rights.
An anti government sit-in at Dakars Place de lIndependance drew at least 3,000 protesters.
Authorities claim they have foiled an coup attempt. Four detained.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: The Senegalese army clashed with separatists in the southern Casamance region on Saturday, leaving three soldiers dead and several others wounded, according to the military.
About 200 disabled Senegalese former soldiers held a two-hour demonstration Friday on a busy Dakar street to call for better pay and health coverage, an AFP correspondent saw.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A Senegalese military vehicle hit a landmine in the restive southwestern province of Casamance on Friday, killing two soldiers and wounding ""several others,"" a security source said.""Our men were on patrol when their vehicle hit an anti-tank mine at Djifangar,"" in northern Casamance, the source said, without specifying the number of injured.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Armed men presumed to be separatist rebels attacked a village in Senegals troubled Casamance region Friday, looting shops and killing a young man, a security source and a witness told AFP. ""A group of rebels burst into the village of Djinbanar at dawn,"" about 110km (63 miles) from Kolda, one of the main cities in the southern region, the source said on condition of anonymity.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A Senegalese soldier was killed and two others injured when their vehicle hit a landmine in the countries troubled Casamance region, a military official said Sunday.

Senegalese police lobbed tear gas at thousands of protesters in the capital yesterday to oppose proposed changes to the constitution. Clouds of tear gas enveloped the square in front of parliament, where lawmakers gathered to deliberate on the proposals.

Senegal deployed extra troops at ministry buildings, armored personnel carriers near the presidential palace and at least one helicopter gunship in the capital Dakar on Tuesday after riots over lengthy power cuts. Many Dakar homes and businesses have been without electricity for more than 30 hours, catalyzing anti-government sentiment. Overnight, demonstrators burnt tires and ransacked the offices of state electricity company Senelec and ministers homes.
Property destruction: Muslim Senegalese youths have destroyed a Jehovahs Witness temple, accusing its followers of spreading alcohol consumption among the population.

Senegal deployed extra troops at ministry buildings, armored personnel carriers near the presidential palace and at least one helicopter gunship in the capital Dakar on Tuesday after riots over lengthy power cuts. Many Dakar homes and businesses have been without electricity for more than 30 hours, catalyzing anti-government sentiment. Overnight, demonstrators burnt tires and ransacked the offices of state electricity company Senelec and ministers homes.

Senegal deployed extra troops at ministry buildings, armored personnel carriers near the presidential palace and at least one helicopter gunship in the capital Dakar on Tuesday after riots over lengthy power cuts. Many Dakar homes and businesses have been without electricity for more than 30 hours, catalyzing anti-government sentiment. Overnight, demonstrators burnt tires and ransacked the offices of state electricity company Senelec and ministers homes.

Senegal deployed its military on Wednesday to clamp down on antigovernment riots after protesters attacked government buildings and burned tires, following a week of sporadic protests that have jolted the leadership of one of Africas most stable countries. The military deployment in the capital, Dakar, appeared to have cleared the streets of protesters, though some have vowed to continue agitating against the government of octogenarian President Abdoulaye Wade.

Thousands filled a sandy plaza here to demonstrate against Senegal's president, Abdoulaye Wade, who is trying to extend his time in office in what critics say is a violation of the country's Constitution.

Young protesters seeking to oust Senegals aging president filled the streets outside a central courthouse in the capital, Dakar, on Tuesday, a day after the police arrested a rapper and prominent democracy activist.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Senegals army clashed Friday with suspected rebels in the southern province of Casamance, the army and local sources said, but there were no immediate details of casualties. Soldiers guarding a road ""were fired on by the rebels near the village of Diango,"" 50 kilometers (30 miles) from the provincial capital Ziguinchor, a military source told AFP.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Suspected rebels blocked off about 50 vehicles and robbed passengers, injuring four people.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A gang of suspected separatist rebels shot dead on civilian and another injured in an attack in Senegals restive southern province of Casamance, in the villages of Medina Peul and Palone.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A gang of suspected separatist rebels shot dead on civilian and another injured in an attack in Senegals restive southern province of Casamance.
Several hundred Senegalese opposition supporters demonstrated Friday against 85-year-old President Abdoulaye Wades bid for a third term in next years elections.
Two people died thiswhen a clash erupted over the establishment of a biofuel project by Italian investors.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Senegals army says 10 people have been killed by separatist rebels in the countries restive south.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A division within MFDC denied and condemned the attacks of rebel forces on the army on 13th Dec 2011 when several soldiers were killed. Five soldiers were missiong following the clash later to be discovered as MFDC POWs.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Rebels of the Casamance Movement of Democratic Forces (MFDC) staged a dawn attack on a government outpost in Diegoune district, 45 kilometers (30 miles) northwest of Ziguinchor, the regions capital. Five rebels and one soldier were killed in the clash, which also left one soldier missing and one soldier and six rebels wounded, the army public relations unit said in a statement sent to AFP.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: At least 12 people, including five Senegalese soldiers, have been killed after suspected rebels attacked an army base in the southern Casamance region.
One is dead of a gunshot wound when rival political parties clash.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A paramilitary group comes under attack from separatist rebels. One officer dead, five troops injured and one missing.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A paramilitary outpost come under attack for the second time in as many days leaving three officers injured.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: MDFC rebels steal food, supplies and automobiles from villagers.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Military forces bomb rebel positions following an attack on civilians over the weekend.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: At least five Senegalese soldiers were wounded when their vehicle was hit by an MFDC anti-tank mine in the south.

Opponents of Senegals President Abdoulaye Wade protested just days before a ruling on the legality of his controversial bid to seek a third term in February polls. Supporters of the president were also active in another region of the city.
Security Measures: The government placed a ban on protests to prevent violence for five days leading up to an election and court decision.

Despite a protest ban the opposition June 23 Movement staged a protest against the incumbent. Police and protesters/rioters clashed late in the day after it was announce the current president could run for an unprecedented third term. A police officer was reported dead following the event. An AFP journalist was assaulted during the melee.

Senegalese police arrested a top member of Senegals M23 opposition movement and prominent local rights activist Alioune Tine a day after the riots. The movement called for renewed protests and many supported gather outside the police division headquarters.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Three soldiers are killed in a MFDC attack.
Two people were killed Monday in northern Senegal during clashes between security forces and opposition members protesting President Abdoulaye Wades reelection bid. Five others injured.

column7: RND: National Democratic Rally; June 23 Movement
column17: Senegal riot police fired tear gas and sprayed protesters with water to break up a thousands-strong rally in the capital demanding that President Abdoulaye Wade drop plans to seek a third term. Angry youths had taunted security forces shortly before the dispersion, throwing rocks at police. One death of a youth reported.
Students at the University of Dakar clash with police a day after a fellow classmate was killed in the Tuesday riots. A bus was set on fire and one student killed in the clashes.

Thousands of protesters have gathered in a Dakar square to demand that octogenarian president Abdoulaye Wade scrap plans to seek a third term in office. Unrest occurred when a group of 50 youth began throwing rocks at police.
Protesters poured in to the capitals Obelisk Square, the epicentre of the months-old protest movement against Wade, as anti-riot police looked on.
Senegals opposition marched through central Dakar to ratchet up the pressure for octogenarian President Abdoulaye Wade to withdraw his candidacy for a controversial third term in office.
Clashes erupted between Senegalese security forces and anti-government demonstrators in the regional capital of Thies, where the countries aging president was planning to hold a campaign rally.

A crowd of about 3,000 answered the call of Yen A Marre, a youth movement whose name means ""Enough is Enough,"" to come to Dakars Obelisk Square to protest the candidacy of Abdoulaye Wade. The protested lasted for several day with the protested sleeping in the square.
Day two of the protest organized by Yen A Marre.
Day three of the protest organized by Yen A Marre.
Unidentified men pillaged a Ziguinchor suburb over the course of two days.
Day four of the protest organized by Yen A Marre. Police dispersed the crowd.

Riot police fired tear gas in side streets around Independence Square and chased small groups of people attempting to come closer as the normally bustling centre of town to protest despite a government ban. Clashes followed, one dead.
Senegal riot police fired teargas at protesters in new clashes Saturday a week ahead of presidential elections.
Senegalese police fired tear gas on stone-throwing demonstrators after prayers at a mosque in the Senegalese capital. Three killed, several injured.
June 23 Movement protesters gather in Dakars city centre.
Police violently disperse protesters in a Dakar suburb, one confirmed dead.

In Thies, people march in a protest for the delocalisation of Sam market

ver 1,000 people participated in a silent march through the streets of Ziguinchor on 22 May, organized by the Women's Peace Platform, to push for the hostages to be freed.

A fisherman, arrested following a dispute between neighbours, died from ill-treatment and torture by soldiers.
The inhabitants of the town of Ourossogui rallied against the neglect of the government against them and urged them to do more to mitigate potential flooding in the coming winter.
Youth of the Alliance for the Republic (APR) disrupted a meeting of the Department of Pikine at the local headquarters of the party.

A clash occurred between villagers of Medina Beye and those of Ndiobene Galo in the rural community of Keur Soce over land issues . The village leader Sheikh Omar Medina Beye Beye was killed and 17 others were seriously injured.
Youths on Friday night burned tyres and other objects as they were outraged by a 24-hour power cut.
Students of Universite Cheikh Anta Diop (UCAD) have taken two Tata buses hostage as they were frustrated waiting for their school assistance.
A military vehicle hit a mine in Kandon on Wednesday, killing one and wounding one.

Violent clashes between vendors and residents occurred at the Castors market between market residents and street vendors following an operation to decongest the streets. Several were wounded, property was damaged, and 10 were arrested.

Outraged by the floods, people of Thiaroye Kao 2, Yeumbeul, march to the local hall to protest against the effect of the floods on the community.
Dozens of people participated in a walk from the premesis of the NGO Horizons Without Borders to denounce killings of Senegalese people abroad.

People throw stones at the house of a policeman in response to his shooting into a crowd.

column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Sud Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: Supporters of Rufisque mayor Badara Sene Mamaya beat and seriously injured two journalists for taking pictures of during clashes with another group; a journalist who came to their aid was also beaten and seriously injured

Clashes occurred between activists of Bennoo Bokk Yaakar and the Senegalese Democratic Party around the village of Maka Kolibantang; stones were thrown at the PDS activists and fighting ensued; several PDS activists were injured
Clashes occurred between activists of Bennoo Bokk Yaakar and the APR when their caravans met in the neighborhood of Amadou Dia Leonat; stones were thrown and at least 4 people were injured

A PDS caravan clashed with APR supporters after a youth brought out a placard disparaging the PDS leader; stones were thrown by the APR supporters; three were injured on the APR side while 6 were injured on the PDS side
The same mob burned down the house of the ""Coordinator"" who was the one who made the remarks about the politician the rioters support; they also burned down a bakery he owned
The home of the Vice President of the National Assembly was burned down by a mob angry about remarks made about a politician they support

Peasants from Bignona blocked the National Route 4 to demand payments from groundnut marketing; they were dispersed peacefully by the gendarmerie, but promised to be back if their demands were not met
A Taxawu Dakar caravan was engaged in violence with unidentified assailants, likely supporters of another list in the local elections

Clashes occurred between the Alternative Vision for Senegal (VISAS) coalition and the Coalition ""Lengo Ligueyal Senegal""; 2 were recorded injured on each side; one of the VISAS candidates was arrested; gunfire was heard during the clashes
Supporters from Khalifa Salls caravan clashed with supporters of Taxawu Dakar headed by Adama Diallo ; no injuries were reported
Two members of the ""Alliances 2014 Aye Mu NEEX"" were seriously injured in clashes with ""thugs"" from Mbaye Ndiaye (BBY)
Supporters from Khalifa Salls caravan threw a ""gas bomb"" into a crowd after supporters of another candidate started a chant against Khalfi Salls caravan

The Ziguinchor airport was the scene of clashes between Benno Bokk Yakaar supporters and supporters of the outgoing mayor; the bodyguard of one of the higher ups in BBY fired shots into the air during the clashes; no injuries reported
Violence broke out between two factions of the PDS while Abdoulaye Wades caravan passed through Podor; some people blocked the road, which led to the scenes of violence and some serious injuries
An altercation broke out when an early closure of voting was announced, but the mayor and police were able to stop further violence

The Collective of Congolese Students of UCAD staged a sit-in outside the Congo-Brazzaville embassy to draw attention to their demands of their government to support them in registration at Senegalese schools
