Women staged a demonstration on the streets of Guediawaye and Wakinane to protest against water shortages in these suburbs

UCS activists gathered in front of the Court of Repression of Illicit Enrichment (CREI) to support their leader, mayor Abdoulaye Balde; a large contingent of police standing by dispersed the activists forcibly, firing tear gas and causing a stampede, prompting some activists to throw rocks at police; the mayors aunt fainted due to the tear gas; the mayor alleges the police threw a tear gas cannister into his car and followed him as he attempted to leave
Dozens of people protested the non-respect of human rights by Gambian authorities.

Youth supporters of the old mayor of Medina engaged in destruction of property, burning down the community house and attacking people with stones, machetes and clubs. At least two municipal officials were injured.

Youth supporters of the old mayor of Medina ransacked the community house, shops and cybercafes in the Medina Commune of Dakar after the installation of the new mayor of the area. Several people were injured with clubs and machetes, and three people, including the former mayor Ndiatbe, were arrested.
Police fired teargas to disperse hundreds of supporters of Karim Wade who had gathered outside the court where his trial is ongoing.

The population of Balantacounda near the Guinea-Bissau border complain that there has been continuous cattle raiding since the beginning of the year from Guinea-Bissau, with recent raid resulting in a man being shot. They have begun refusing Guinea-Bissauians entry to their village in response.

column16: Media Foundation for West Africa; Agence de Presse Senegalaise
column17: Police used tear gas to break up a student demonstration. Violent clashes between police and students followed, including rock throwing. One student was killed and several others were injured after police stormed a hall of residence.
7 people were killed and 3 wounded when a wagon carrying 10 youths hit a landmine.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Armed kidnappers believed to be part of the MFDC took 9 community outreach workers and a soldier prisoner. They were released about 15 hours later with no harm done to them.

Youth in Ourossogui marched to protest against the modification to turn a building into offices. They attacked the town hall, throwing stones and other objects, causing some injuries and damage to the property. 11 people were arrested by police.
Residents of District 25 engaged in a sit-in to demand better santization of their area due to constant septic tank overflows.
Municipal councillors and officials held a sit-in to protest against blocking of funds for various reasons in the city.
Rail workers marched to denounce the deterioration of their vehicles and demand they be fixed.
Workers of the Radio Television Senegal (RTS) angry about the ending of fixed term contracts for some of their colleagues, covered the RTS building in red armbands in protest.

column6: Police Forces of Senegal (2012-) Prison Guards
column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Sud Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: 1 inmate was killed and 2 injured after a riot broke out at Tambacounda prison, during which some prisoners tried to steal a gun and break out.
Bus drivers in Ziguinchor demonstrated to denounce a new transport system being introduced.

Construction workers working on National Road No.6 erected barricades and burned tires, stopping traffic at the Goudomp/Tanaff intersection, to demand two months salary arrears and poor working conditions.
A police officer allegedly beat a bus passenger, generating widespread anger amongst bus drivers in Grand Yoff.
Bus drivers took to the streets to express anger at alleged police harassment earlier that day. They burned tires on the main road of Grand Yoff. Police responded with gunfire and tear gas
About 100 farmers from several counties of the Sedhiou region took part in a sit-in to protest against the impunity of cattle rusters in the area.

column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Sud Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: Graduates of the Faculty of Science and Technology Education and Training (FASTEF) occupied a hall at the University Cheikh Anta Diop (UCAD) to demand the government recruit them to the public service. They also started a hunger strike.
Inhabitants of Mbao held a protest against a proposed transfer of land in the area to a private company.
Medical staff in the Sedhiou region took part in a sit-in after their general meeting to decide on measures to demand the government satisfy their demands.

Demonstrators took to the streets to protest against high electricity bills. They burned tires on roads throughout the area and armed themselves with stones. Police suppressed the protest and arrested dozens of people.
Students marched to demand an end to power shortages in the city.
Clashes broke out between merchants evicted from their shops and police after the merchants burned tires and blocked the Patte dOie bridge.

Ranchers and farmers in the Seedo locality of Matam engaged in clashes which led to 4 injured before police could intervene. They arrested 1. The clashes were said to have started due to cattle grazing on farmers lands.
Despite fears that the event would be banned, the PDS held a large rally to protest against the government and let people air their frustrations.
Students at Cheikh Anta Diop University protested for higher scholarships, blocking the road with rocks.
Civil society groups and women from Kolda marched in protest of the conditions of a regional hospital.
A conflict between farmers and herders led to two serious injuries when unidentified men attacked two separate herders and their cattle.
A relative of the mayor of Karantaba was seriously injured in a knife attack, believed to be related to an ongoing political crisis in the community after an annulment of a mayoral election.

Students in Niani engaged in clashes with the police following protests, resulting in 5 wounded on both sides. Students set up barricades along National Highway 1 to Tambacounda, committed acts of vandalism and threw stones at police. Police used tear gas in response.
A gang of 3 thieves crossed the border from Guinea-Bissau and attempted to steal some motorcycles from Sindima. A vigilante militia pursued them and fatally wounded one of them.
Members of the tourism industry marched ""to seek development of viable and sustainable solutions to the ills of their sector.""
Health workers affiliated with the Independent Union of Health protested against the ""bad social climate prevailing in their hospital"". They engaged in a sit-in at their hospital.
Evicted merchants rioted, throwing stones at the town hall and burning tires on the road. Police responded, arresting 11 merchants. 5 people were injured and property was damaged.
Municipal officials from two neighbouring districts brawled over revenues from a market which falls between their jurisdictions.
Staff of the Faculty of Science and Technology in Education and Training (FASTEF) protested against delays in pay, blocking a road with large rocks and trees.

119 contract employees of the municipality protested to demand unpaid wages and because they may lose their jobs soon. Police attempted to disperse the protesters with tear gas, but allegedly hit a youth who was not part of the protest, seriously injuring him.

column7: SAES: Independent Union of Higher Education
column17: Members of the SAES marched on UCAD market to demand the invalidation of a law that they say is aimed at reducing the rights of universities.
Keur Massar market traders marched on town hall and protested against increases to municipal taxes which affect them.
Inter-local government workers marched to demand solutions to salary delays and the implementation of social protection measures, among other issues.
Students and teachers of Keur Massar resettlement high school marched to denounce poor working conditions.

Hundreds of Senegalese Muslims marched to protest the publications of cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad by Charlie Hebdo. They protested in front of the French embassy and allegedly burned a French flag.
Members of the League of Young Muslims Dahra (North) protested against the publication of cartoons of the Prophet Mohammad by Charlie Hebdo.
Muslims marched in protest of recent caricatures of the prophet Mohammed in the French journal Charlie Hebdo.
Hundreds of Muslims marched in protest of the recent French journal ""Charlie Hebdo"" caricatures of the prophet Mohammed and against President Macky Salls solidarity with France.

column9: UJTL: Union of Liberal Young Workers
column17: Arrests: Leaders of the UJTL, Toussaint Manga and Marie Sow Ndaiye, were arrested for trying to hold a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Justice.
Four people armed with gas canisters and tires set a bus on fire at Dakar Dem Dikk. It is possible that they were from the Senegalese Democratic Party and at least one has been arrested.
Muslim leaders organized a sit-in against the French publication Charlie Hebdos recent caricatures of the prophet Mohammed.
Hundreds gathered in front of Dakars Grand Mosque after Friday prayers to denounce French publication Charlie Hebdos caricatures of the prophet.
Muslim leaders organized a sit-in against the French publication Charlie Hebdos recent caricatures of the prophet Mohammed.
Around 1,500 people including the prime minister marched against the French publication Charlie Hebdos caricatures of the prophet Mohammed. Some demonstrators burned the French flag.
Demonstrators blocked National Highway No. 6 to demand that soldiers remain at the Marsaglia military position.

column16: AFP; Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Sud Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: The government banned a PDS planned sit-in at the Obelisk in Dakar. Still, tens of people tried to hold the protest and security forces stopped them with tear gas and arrested several leaders.

column7: FPDR: Patriotic Front for the Defense of the Republic
column17: FPDR supporters, including many from the PDS, held a sit-in at the Obelisk square, despite a government ban. Police dispersed them using tear gas.

column7: FPDR: Patriotic Front for the Defense of the Republic
column17: Former President Abdoulaye Wade led a march of hundreds of activists in favor of releasing political prisoners.
Education sector unions held a sit-in in front of the Academy Inspections office and the office of Inspections of Education and Training as part of a larger protest movement.
Carpenters held a peaceful protest against excessive cutting of trees and wasting of the forests resources.
Dozens demonstrated to raise awareness of the issues surrounding child begging, including the death of nine children in a fire in a Koranic school two years ago which was related to child begging.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.

column7: SAES: Independent Union of Higher Education; Teachers (Senegal)
column17: Teachers from the SAES union protested against proposed suspension of salaries.
With support from the Ministry of Women, Family and Child Protection, women marched in protest of female genital mutilation.

Gaston Berger University students protested and set up road blocks with burning tires and trailers to show their opposition to the framework law reorganizing public universities. Police used tear gas to diseprse the crowds. No casualties or arrests were reported.

After Karim Wade, the son of the former president, was convicted on corruption charges, young supporters took to the streets in Dakar where they burned tires and threw stones at police who responded with tear gas.
Villagers protested against lack of political action on water and electricity.

column7: SUTSAS: Trade Union of Health Workers and Social Action
column17: Protesters held a sit-in at a health clinic to demand compensation for victims of a recent mining accident and improved working conditions.
Teachers walked out of work and marched to demand that the government respect the agreements they signed last year. Protests took place in 14 district capitals.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Soldiers clashed with alleged MFDC rebels, near Siganar in the forest of Basse Casamance, leading to several wounded. The report gave the impression that the clash was an accidental incident.
Cheikh Anta Diop University students held a sit-in to express solidarity with the victims of the Garissa militant attack in Kenya.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A soldier was wounded in a clash with MFDC rebels which was believed to be in retaliation for an incident on Apr.8.
Students from several schools in the town of Bignona organized a peaceful march to demand the end to an ongoing ""school crisis.""

column7: SUTSAS: Trade Union of Health Workers and Social Action
column17: Members of SUTSAS engaged in a national sit-in in all hospital and health caentres while maintaining minimum service to demand government compliance with agreements signed in 2014.
Students from three public high schools in Ziguinchor organized a march to demand a solution to the ""school crisis.""
Students demonstrated outside the offices of the Virtual University of Senegal to demand educational materials promised by the government.

Police clashed with students while attempting to disperse protests related to scholarships. After 4 of their colleagues were arrested, students took 2 police officers hostage, with all 6 individuals being released after negotiations.
Students marched in solidarity with the Kenyan University of Garissa in light of a recent attack there.
Protesters blocked President Macky Sall from a political reception. Police intervened when one protester laid down in the road to prevent entry into the city.
Hundreds of women from civil society organizations from the Sedhiou region marched in favor of Casamance peace negotiations.
Groups in favor of and opposed to the construction of a new mosque clashed, seriously injuring several. Police and gendarmes came, but it calmed without their involvement.
Dozens of women from three departments in the Louga region marched for increased women's representation in peace negotiations in Casamance.

Civil society organizations held a sit-in in front of the DRC Embassy to demand the release of young Congolese activists who have been detained since March in Kinshasa. The government of Senegal subsequently banned the demonstration.
Women organized a march in support of the Casamance peace process.
Civil society organizations marched to protest sending Senegalese toops to fight in Yemen.

column7: SYSED: Senegalese Synergy for Education and Development; Students (Senegal)
column17: Young students under the direction of the SYSED union marched in Kolda to demand better traffic safety in construction zones near schools.
6 students from University Assane Seck tried to march from Ziguinchor to Dakar in protest of conditions at the school, but they were arrested when the arrived at Bignona.

column7: CNTS: National Union of Senegalese Workers
column17: Workers from the National Union of Senegalese Workers held a peaceful march in support of 600 workers who were recently dismissed by the national electricity directorate.
Police trying to declutter a railway station clashed with street vendors, resulting in fires in several shops.
Hundreds of children marched in protest of violence against children.
Police and street vendors clashed in the same area where shops were recently burned.
Citizens of Malika held a sit-in outside the city hall to demand government arbitration of an environmental dispute.
Secondary school teachers, students, and parents marched to protest the construction of a restaurant in front of the school.
Attijariwafa bank agents held a sit-in at headquarters to demand the right to to gain credit at the bank.

column9: Police Forces of Senegal (2012-); Government of Senegal (2012-)
column17: Protesters came out in droves and burned tires to express discontent with the mayor of Patte dOie regarding a dispute over a rainwater receptacle. They clashed with municipality leaders, which led to two serious injuries and four arrests.
In a continuation of a dispute between residents and government leaders over rainwater collection, residents took the streets with knives and clashes led to two new injuries and four new arrests.
Residents of the Grand Standing quarter of Thies West protested poor land management, including plans to build a gas station.
Protesters were prevented from marching but still grouped publicly to express their outrage over the recent kidnapping of a 4 year old girl in Rufisque.

12 loggers were abducted by an armed gang near Kolling (lat/longs not available) in the Casamance region. The kidnappers demanded a ransom and they were later released on Jul.12. Local media believed that the kidnappers may have been a splinter of the MFDC.
Protesters from Bamacounda, Malifara and Kountoubou marched to demand electrification of their villages by SENELEC.

Students threw stones at the motorcade of President Macky Sall during his visit to University Cheikh Anta Diop in Dakar. Several were arrested though it remains unclear whether any student group perpetrated the event.

column7: ACSIF: Association of Clients and Members of Financial Institutions
column17: The Association of Clients and Members of Financial Institutions (ACSIF) held a sit-in on Independence Square against ""large scale scams"" by the banking sector. The protest was broken up by police and at least 5 members of ACSIF were arrested.

Residents of Tanaff protested for the immediate removal of the chief of nurses due to supposed finanical misconduct. Police intervened to escort the accused to police headquarters for his protection though no injuries or damage was reported.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: MFDC attacked vehicles, robbing the passengers and raping a woman before escaping into the forest as the military arrived.

Despite a government ban, PDS opposition members held a march in Dakar and dozens of police officers responded by blocking paths and using teargas. They arrested 16, including former chief of staff to President Wade, Papa Samba Mboup, and activist Marie Aw.

column7: FPDR: Patriotic Front for the Defense of the Republic; PDS: Senegalese Democratic Party
column17: Activists from the FPDR and PDS met at the Obelisk in Dakar to hold a rally, but the numbers were small as perhaps thousands were blocked on sidestreets by police and others were afraid to of potential clashes with police.
Protesters from 12 villages came together to protest the building of a hydraulic canal.
Environmentalists confronted vendors illegally gathering beach sand for resale and the two groups came to blows, leaving several injured.

Supporters of former Chadian dictator Habre had to be forcibly removed after they charged the front of the court where he is being tried. Habre had to be ""dragged"" to the trial as well - at one point it took four security guards in face masks to hold him down.
A mob beat to death a man found trying to rob their neighbor.
227 former government employees marched to demand new public jobs. Police and gendarme stopped the protesters.
Protesters marched to demand the demolition of a dangerous building.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Rebel fighters refused to be searched by authorities, which lead to a firefight. No casualties were reported, and several were arrested.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: MFDC rebels ambushed troops near the village of Badiana, which led to a firefight. Casualties unknown, at least four soldiers wounded.
Opposition activists ""rallied"" outside the headquarters of the Senegalese Democratic Party, calling for the adoption of the Consultation Framework.
Heavy security prevented protesters and journalists from getting near the National Assembly.

Arrests: In the lead up to the International Forum on Peace and Security in Africa, Senegalese security forces arrested an unprecedented number of Muslim clerics suspected of ""militant"" links in Kolda, Guediawaye, Kaolack, and Rufisque.

Arrests: In the lead up to the International Forum on Peace and Security in Africa, Senegalese security forces arrested an unprecedented number of Muslim clerics suspected of ""militant"" links in Kolda, Guediawaye, Kaolack, and Rufisque.

Arrests: In the lead up to the International Forum on Peace and Security in Africa, Senegalese security forces arrested an unprecedented number of Muslim clerics suspected of ""militant"" links in Kolda, Guediawaye, Kaolack, and Rufisque.

Arrests: In the lead up to the International Forum on Peace and Security in Africa, Senegalese security forces arrested an unprecedented number of Muslim clerics suspected of ""militant"" links in Kolda, Guediawaye, Kaolack, and Rufisque.
Protesters held a sit-in against an expansion by the company Salins du Saloum.
An angry mob burned tires and attacked police vehicles transporting 11 people who were arrested on Dec 24 at a gay wedding.
Students protested in front of City Hall to demand subsidies.
Students, teachers and civil society organizations marched to advocate for girls rights.
Unidentified group set fire to Dabo High School, causing major damage. A guard caught one of the perpetrators and handed him over to police.
Local government workers marched to demand payment of salaries.
Around 100 demonstrators from an anti-gay coalition protested against the release of accused homosexuals. Police dispersed protesters and arrested 11 because the protest was unauthorized.

Arrests: Police arrested nearly 900 people in a two-day operation in Dakar and Thies in an effort to prevent potential terror attacks. Soldiers stationed on roads and in buildings and carry out searches.
Protesters marched against the recent publication by Jeune Afrique of a controversial cartoon depicting a Mouride religious leader.
Mouride Muslims marched to denounce a cartoon recently published by Jeune Afrique.
Dozens of Mouride Muslims marched to protest a recent cartoon published by Jeune Afrique.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A Senegalese soldier was injured during a shootout with alleged Casamance rebels.
Students burnt tyres and erected roadblocks in Saint-Louis to protest against the prices of accommodation in town.
Transporters blocked the road into Gambia in protest against increased taxes on Senegalese trucks.
About three hundred people held a sit-in at town hall to demand the mayors resignation.
Merchants marched in protest of raised taxes and threw objects at police who tried to stop them.

column7: SAES: Independent Union of Higher Education; Teachers (Senegal)
column17: Teachers marched in protest of the states alleged violations of recent agreements with their union.
Villagers marched to protest lack of water and electricity.

column7: SAES: Independent Union of Higher Education; Teachers (Senegal)
column17: Trade unions staged a protest march on Wednesday in Cheikh Anta Diop University in Dakar. They demand the respect of agreements from the part of the government.
Rioters attack members of the socialist party at a meeting in Dakar and ransack the offices. At least one injured and several party officials later arrested.
Opposing political groups clashed while campaigning on an upcoming referendum. Gendarmes intervened.
Students demonstrated against government recruitment decisions, stopping traffic and clashing with security forces.
Opposing political groups clashed while campaigning for an upcoming referendum. Minor injuries reported.
Security forces ""violently repressed"" students protesting in front of the Ministry of Education. One student potentially seriously injured by bullet.
Protesters marched to advocate for human rights and political freedoms in neighboring Gambia.

column8: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Army clashed with rebels while destroying cannabis farms. ""Heavy losses"" reported on side of rebels and one soldier injured.
Students held an unauthorized march to demand release of transcripts. Protest organizer Abdou Aziz Seck later arrested and released.
Unionists marched to commemorate Labor Day and demand better working conditions.
Unionists marched to commemorate Labor Day and draw attention to a wide range of grievances.
Sit-it of protest against the Communal Council accused of deliberately sold 36 hectares of land to a religious leader.
Drivers briefly blocked the Dahra-Touba route to protest continued contstruction and detours.
Soldier on leave killed by unknown group.
Hundreds of fruit farmers rallied to protest destruction of fields in Kantene, just south of Ziguinchor.
A peaceful protest was held in Mbao to denounce chemical emissions from a local industry.

Violent clashes erupted in Mbao between protesters and police in Mbao, where demonstrators were protesting against the chemical emissions of an industry nearby. The security officers fired teargas to disperse the demonstrators.
Opposing groups within the Mandingue community in Mbour clashed over Kankourang rituals, leaving four people injured and two people arrested.

column8: Police Forces of Senegal (2012-) Prison Guards
column17: Clashes between prisoners and prison guards at the Rebeuss prison in Dakar as a group of up to 700 prisoners attempted to escape during visits throwing rocks at the guard. One prison guard was shot dead and 41 injured, including 14 guards.

Opposing youth groups within the Mandingue community in Mbour clashed over Kankourang rituals, leaving around 15 people injured. One of the youth groups had set up road blocks and burnt tyres on the road outside a Kankourang, leading to the clashes. Police forces later intervened using tear gas to disperse them.

Opposing youth groups within the Mandingue community in Mbour clashed over Kankourang rituals, leaving around 15 people injured. One of the youth groups had set up road blocks and burnt tyres on the road outside a Kankourang, leading to the clashes. Police forces later intervened using tear gas to disperse them.

column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Dakar7; Senenews
column17: A group of 50 rioters reportedly ransacked the headquarters of the REWMI party in Diamalaye in Dakar, injuring dozens of supporters during a meeting of the party.
Bus drivers in Ziguinchor refused to pay fees at the bus station for several days in protest against lack of transparency in the management of these funds.

column9: FDS: Front for the Defence of Senegal
column17: Police clashed with up to 3,000 opposition members gathered in the Front for the Defence of Senegal (FDS) protesting in Dakar to demand more liberties and more transparency in the management of gaz and other natural resources recently discovered in Senegal. The rioters clashed with police forces when they tried to force their way through them and threw rocks to follow their initial itinirary (which had been modified by the government to avoid central areas of the town). Police fired tear gas to disperse the rioters, leaving several people injured, and arrested five rioters. The five were released 48h later.
Police clashed with youth in Guet-Ndar opposed to the demolition operations of two mosques in the neighborhood, including due to machine breakdown. Police threw tear gas to disperse the youth.
Unknown gunmen attacked and killed two pharmacy employees in Ndioum, Podor department. No goods were stolen.
Around a hundred youths protested in Kolda against female genital mutilation and early marriage.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: MFDC gunmen kidnapped a team of ten people in charge of mapping the creation of new roads to promote local development in Bayanka village, 20km from the border with Gambia. MFDC opposes more traffic in the area that would compromise their rebel activities.

Clashes between police forces and youth protesting against the planned demolition of two mosques in Guet-Ndar neighborhood of Saint-Louis. The protesters ransacked a school in the clash. 20 were later arrested.
Unknown assailants killed a man in Abene, west of Bignona.

Gunmen raped and killed a woman in Bignona, Ziguinchor. Members of the Gendarmerie arrested one of the suspects the following day. Angry residents later invaded the Gendarmerie and threw rocks, asking for the suspect to lynch him. The suspect was transferred to Ziguinchor.

Gunmen raped and killed a woman in Bignona, Ziguinchor. Members of the Gendarmerie arrested one of the suspects the following day. Angry residents later invaded the Gendarmerie and threw rocks, asking for the suspect to lynch him. The suspect was transferred to Ziguinchor.
Children march in Kolda, calling for the protection of their right, including through the fight against early marriage and pregnancy.
Members of the Committee for the Fight against Violence Against Women (CLVF) as well as other supporters marched in Kaolack, calling for an end to sexual and gender-based violence in the country.
Clashes between youth of the ruling Alliance for the Republic (APR) early December, leaving several injured.

Civil society organisations marched in Dakar to support efforts by local regional and international organisationsto urge current Gambian president to concede his defeat in the latest presidential elections.
Education authorities, citizens and activists marched in Kolda to call for an end to violence against children and girls in the country.
2 people were killed when they were attacked in the town of Sakar in the Sedhiou district.
The headquarters of the ruling Alliance for the Republic (APR) in Fatick are ransacked by unknown individuals.

Young socialists dressed up in red chanted slogans to protest accusations made against some officials of the Party over an attack at a party meeting on 5 March. They were dispersed by authorities and police present at the Court in Dakar.
A group of students protested in Bignona over a money subsidy, burning tyres on the road, vandalising public property and attacking public function workers. They were later arrested.

Hundreds of people demonstrated in Sedhiou to protest lack of human capital and infrastructure development in the region. Members of the military police intervened to stop the protest as they were reportedly only allowed to gather.

Clashes between members of a Muslim Church and populations denouncing authorities' failure to resolve the land issue between the two groups, in Madinatoul Salam village near Keur Samba Laobe, left several people injured, including one seriously.

Arrests: Senegalese security officials arrested in Karang four senior members of former president Jammeh's presidential guard accused of numerous documented assassinations. He reportedly fled Gambia upon Jammeh's stepping down from power.
Clashes between rival APR supporters in Mbao over voter registration. Registration activities closed as a result and resumed the following week.
Clashes between APR factions at the party's headquarters in Zinguichor as crowds of supporters and local representatives gathered to attend the party's general assembly.

column6: Military Forces of Senegal (2012-) Border Guards
column17: Altercation between border guards and a group of gold miners at Khossanto in Kedougou region led to the death of one of the miners. The two border guards were later arrested.
Rioters vandalised three public buses in Dakar after a conference by supporters of Dakar Mayor Khalifa Sall.

Dozens of residents of Kedougou, mainly students, marched in Dakar calling for justice for the death of a gold miner by a border guard at Khossanto a few days prior and for better partition of exploitation revenues.

Moroccan students held a sit-in in front of their embassy in Dakar following the killing of a Moroccan student in an armed robbery. They protested discrimination and insecurity targeting them in the county.
Clashes between demonstrators and police in Dakar's Grand-Yoff following the announcement of Dakar's Mayor imprisonment over corruption allegations.

column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Sud Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: Angry motorbike drivers set up road blocks, burnt tyres and vandalized property including the lcoal police station over two days in Kolda to protest the injury of one of their colleagues during a road control by policemen. On the second day, police and army intervenes to calm the situation down. Several people were injured. 38 suspects were later arrested in connection with the events, including five charged with two-three months imprisonment.

column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Sud Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: Angry motorbike drivers set up road blocks, burnt tyres and vandalized property including the lcoal police station over two days in Kolda to protest the injury of one of their colleagues during a road control by policemen. On the second day, police and army intervenes to calm the situation down. Several people were injured. 38 suspects were later arrested in connection with the events, including five charged with two-three months imprisonment.

Clashes between APR supporters in Dakar's Pikine involving fist fights and throwing of rocks at each other left several injured. The clash occurred at a party meeting to elect a new Coordinator in the area.

Supporters of Dakar officials vandalised public buses in Dakar after the General Prosecutor maintained prison charges for former Mayor Bamba Fall and seven co-accused for the ransacking of the offices of the socialist party in March 2016. Dakar's Appels Court had earlier lifted prison charges for the eight accused.

Thousands of Senegalese, including members of the PDS, joined the movement ""Y en a marre"" in the streets of Dakar to protest lack of democracy and justice in the country. Among others, they denounced the regular detention of members of the opposition and excessive state debt.

Grand Party youth supporters threw stones at police and burnt tyres on the road as police forces fired tear gas to disperse them at a party rally at Djidah Thiaroye Kao of Pikine. Police arrested the Grand Party leader as well as 10 youths.
Students from the national education and training institute for young blind people marched in Thies to protest the expulsion of six of theirs following violent conduct towards a younger student.
People's march for the liberation of Dakar Mayor was blocked by policemen. The situation was tense but did not degenerate.
Hundreds of journalists and press entrepreneurs demonstrated against the worrying situation of media in Senegal.
N'Drame youth organised a march to complain about the infrastructural policy implemented in their municipality.

While waiting for the Youth Minister Mame Mbaye Niang, Mr Mael Diop allegedly set up a group of youngsters to attack the organisers of event (Cojer of Fass/Gueule-Tapee/Colobane). Once the delegation arrived, the youngsters aggressed the audience with stones, teargas and teasers.
Opposition coalition Mankoo Taxawu gathered to ask for the liberation of Dakar Mayor Khalifa Sall and the retour of Karim Wade's son.
Truck drivers and transporters protested the absence of a bus station's president.
Custom officers' control provoked some short clashes between some young persons, allegedly smuggglers, and customs officiers.
People demonstrated against the slowness of hospital construction works.
COJER (convergence of republican youth) and supporters of Grand Yoff's municipality Madiop Diop clashed at the Youth Centre.

column7: SAES: Independent Union of Higher Education; Teachers (Senegal)
column17: Teachers went to the streets to claim for better pension conditions.
People protested the lack of electrfication of their village.
Women protested against the electricity breaks.
Clashes between merchants and police forces following a ""security operation"" by the Safinatoul Amane's Dahira: they threw eachothers teargas and stones. Two merchants wounded.
Several personalities of the presidential coalition took part to the demonstration organised by the Benno Bokk Yaakaar coalition.
The ""Mankoo Taxawu Senegaal"" (MTS) claimed its caravan was attacked by unnamed actors.

Police blocked the road and fired teargas in Dakar as dozens of people had gathered to protest the failed delivery of election cards for the upcoming legislative elections. At least six protesters were arrested. The protest was called by former leader Abdoulaye Wade in an area close to the presidential palace that was declared off-limits.

Angry Wattu Senegaal coalition supporters ransacked around 80 polling stations in Touba and besieged the Ndame sub-prefecture due to delays in voting material and the absence of their party representatives on local electoral lists. Police later arrested 3.
Police dispersed with teargas protesters asking for the enforcement of the court's decision about the Boubess market issue.
A cart was hit by an IED: two wounded. First incident of this type since 2014.
Socialist Women association demonstrated in front of the Rebeuss prison asking for the liberation of Dakar Mayor, Khalifa Sall.

Opposition MPs protested against the detention of Dakar Mayor Khalifa Sall, who was not allowed to participate to the first session of the newly-elected National Assembly despite his parlamentary immunity.
Hundreds of persons took the street to protest against the FCFA in Cotonou, Dakar and Bamako.
Agricultural producers went to the street to protest bas working conditions and the inhability of the newly-appointed PRODAC coordinator.
Youngesters from Gouye-Gall neighbourhood blocked the RN2 protesting the modification of the route Gueoul-Saradawo.
The group of people impacted by the regional train project went to the street to protest the low indemnisations proposed in exchange of their parcels. Policemen dispersed the crowd.
Imams and oulemas took the streets in Kalounaye to show their support to the establishment of the Catholic University of Western Africa in Coubalan.
70 fishermen fishing in Mauritanian waters with no licence were pursued by Mauritanian Coast Guards untill in the Senegalese waters. One was shot and he's now in the hospital.

Hundreds of supporters of high-profile Senegalese mayor Khalifa Sall called for his release on Saturday as prosecutors asked parliament to lift his immunity from prosecution on graft charges. Dressed in items of red clothing, activists called for Dakar mayor Sall to be released after serving more than seven months in pre-trial detention on what they say are politically-motivated embezzlement charges. ""Free Khalifa!"" and ""Khalifa until we die!"" chanted around 300 people, many of them women and young people, after gathering a roundabout in the city's Medina district.

The people of Foundiougne went to the street to ask the government to find a solution ""fast and effective"" to the problem of drinking water supply of their municipality and surrounding localities, noted the APS

The members of the ad hoc committee who wanted to hear the mayor of Dakar were met with the determination of his souteneurs. Khalifa Sall's relatives soon blocked all the roads leading to Rebeuss Prison. It took the muscled intervention of the police to disperse them.

In Dakar, about 400 people gathered on the Obelisk Square to denounce the sale of human beings in Libya. Members of civil society, political actors, citizens have come to the platform to denounce this situation.
Young people from the commune of Tambacounda (east) blocked the traffic on the main road of the district Abattoirs to demand the completion of its construction started in 2011.
Senegalese organized a sit-in in Dakar, at the Islamic Institute, to denounce the unrestrained occupation of Palestinian lands
The students of the Cheikh Anta Diop University of Dakar beat the tarmac to demand the payment of scholarships and the reopening of restaurants. While clashing with the forces of order.

Thirteen youths were killed by ""armed elements"" in the Casamance region of southern Senegal. The victims were out collecting wood in the Bayotte forest, 20 kilometres (12 miles) from the regional capital Ziguinchor, ""when they were attacked by an armed band of 15 people"". A source in Ziguinchor said that ""thirteen were killed and two were able to escape"".
A gunman was killed in Senegal's southern Casamance region during a shootout at the weekend with soldiers searching for the killers of 14 men in an area known for its illegal logging networks.
On 16 January 2018, students demonstrated to claim their unpaid allowances in Dakar. [size=no report].

Students demonstrated to claim their unpaid salaries. On the same day, The association ""Kekendo"" gathered students of the University Cheikh Anta Diop (Ucad) of Dakar for the development of Casamance to denounce the killing of Boffa-Bayottes.
Students demonstrated to claim their unpaid salaries. Protesters were throwing rocks, and police riposted by using teargas and burning a room in the campus.
Students demonstrated to claim their unpaid salaries. Protesters were throwing rocks, and police riposted by using teargas.

column8: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A ""rebel"" was killed in new clashes with soldiers in Casamance.

column7: CNTS: National Union of Senegalese Workers
column17: Workers demonstrated to demand better support for their main grievances that can be summarized in ""better working conditions"".

Calm has returned to the city of Saint-Louis in northern Senegal, following violent protests and the looting of shops belonging to Mauritanian nationals on Monday. The violence erupted after the death of a Senegalese fisherman, shot by members of the Mauritanian coast guard.
A Bissau-Guinean was killed and two others injured after a quarrel with Senegalese customs officials at the border.
A thousand opposition supporters demonstrated in Dakar claiming fair elections in 2019.
Dozens of teachers went to the street to ask for the implementation of the agreements subscribed with the government.

column7: SAEMSS: Autonomous Union of Middle and Secondary Teachers of Senegal
column17: Teacher unions went to the street to claim the implementation of the accords signed with the government.
Students demostrated to protest teachers' strikes.
People marched to ask for the end of violence in the region.

column8: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: A Senegalese soldier was killed and another wounded in a military operation targeting ""criminal activities"" by rebels in the country's southern Casamance region.
Supporters of Khalifa Sall gathered in front of the city hall.
In Medina Gounass, a large crowd walked for several kilometres in protest to claim the involvement of youth in decision-making.
Some students from Tambacounda went to the streets to ask for a solution to teachers' strikes.
Police dispersed with teargas a demonstration of Senegalese opposition groups under the Initiative for Democratic Elections (IED).
On Nov 3, the populations of the Langue de Barbarie (Saint-Louis) demonstrated to urge for better preparation against floods to protect fishermen.
On 13 March students went to the street to ask for the end of strikes.
On 13 March students went to the street to ask for the end of strikes.
on 14 March Charles de Gaulle students went to the street to denounce the repeated strikes of teachers.
On 19 March, students in Simbandi Brassou went to the street and erected barricades and burnt tyres on the road no 6 to protest against teachers' strikes.
On 21 March, students of two city high schools went to the street to claim better work conditions.
On 24 March, opposition in Ndondol went to the street to protest the land management by the city mayor.
On 26 March, a march protesting abuses on children was organised in Dakar.
On 30 March, supporters of Dakar mayor Khalifa Sall stormed the tribunal where Sall was judged. They were dispersed by police using teargas.
On 31 March, people from Bemet, Francounda, Sibicouroto and Niassene marched in Sedhiou to support the construction of roads.

column7: CRS: Senegal Red Cross; Aid Workers (Senegal)
column9: CRS: Senegal Red Cross; Aid Workers (Senegal)
column17: On 16 April, some Red Cross staff members vandalised the Red Cross office in Pikine.
On 17 April, Djignabo High School students took the street in Ziguinchor to protest the low quality of education. Police dispersed protesters with teargas.

On 19 April, police fired teargas to break up a protest in Dakar and arrested several people, including a former premier, protesting against a move to raise the bar for presidential candidates. Around 100 demonstrators who had barricaded a street were dispersed.
On 19 April, protests were held in Saint-Louis, Thies and Mbacke against a move to raise the bar for presidential candidates.
On 19 April, protests were held in Saint-Louis, Thies and Mbacke against a move to raise the bar for presidential candidates.
On 19 April, protests were held in Saint-Louis, Thies and Mbacke against a move to raise the bar for presidential candidates.

On 20 April, students went to the streets to ask for the end of teachers' strike and attempted to interrupt courses in private schools in Ziguinchor. During these demonstrations, students set fire to an administration vehicle: police dispersed them with teargas and arrested 20. 14 wounded (including two policemen).
On 21 April 2018, local vigilantes clashed with a group of poachers in the area of Fafacourou (Medina Yoro Foulah, Kolda). One poacher wounded.
On 23 April, a student was wounded in Thies, as students clashed with policemen. Students were protesting against the teachers' strike.
On 23 April, students from Sedhiou commune protested against the teachers' strike paralysing the educational sector.
On 24 April, students from Diattacounda stormed the National Route N6 linking Ziguinchor and Tanaff, protesting against the teachers' strike. They blocked the route with burning tires.
On 28 April, people from the Samine Balante commune went to the streets and barricaded the National Route 6 to protest Bissau-Guineans cattle thefts in the region.
On 1 May, some Red Cross staff members vandalised the Red Cross office in Pikine.
On 2 May, armed men tried to blow up a key bridge in Ziguinchor, Casamance, killing a fisherman. They torched the huts of eight fishermen living underneath the bridge.

On 15 May, students clashed with police in Saint Louis, as they to freely use the university canteens protesting the missing scolarhips payments. In the clashes with police, a student was killed. On the same day, students launched nationwide strikes to protest the death of their colleague.

On 16 May, students clashed with police in Dakar, Ziguinchor, Thies, Bambey, as a student was killed by police during clashes in Saint Louis on 15 May. In Diourbel, students went on strike to protest the killing.

On 16 May, students clashed with police in Dakar, Ziguinchor, Thies, Bambey, as a student was killed by police during clashes in Saint Louis on 15 May. In Diourbel, students went on strike to protest the killing.

On 16 May, students clashed with police in Dakar, Ziguinchor, Thies, Bambey, as a student was killed by police during clashes in Saint Louis on 15 May. In Diourbel, students went on strike to protest the killing.

On 16 May, students clashed with police in Dakar, Ziguinchor, Thies, Bambey, as a student was killed by police during clashes in Saint Louis on 15 May. In Diourbel, students went on strike to protest the killing.
On 16 May, students organised in Saint Louis a march to the spot where a student was killed by police during clashes on 15 May.
On 19 May, people from Dioulacolon, Guiro Yoro Bocar and Salikegne in Kolda erected barricades on the national route to protest the bad conditions of the road
On 19 May, people from Dioulacolon, Guiro Yoro Bocar and Salikegne in Kolda erected barricades on the national route to protest the bad conditions of the road
On 24 May, students took the street in Dakar, Saint-Louis, Ziguinchor, Thies and Babey to claim for justice as to the killing of a student on 15 May in Saint-Louis.
On 24 May, students took the street in Dakar, Saint-Louis, Ziguinchor, Thies and Babey to claim for justice as to the killing of a student on 15 May in Saint-Louis.
On 24 May, students took the street in Dakar, Saint-Louis, Ziguinchor, Thies and Babey to claim for justice as to the killing of a student on 15 May in Saint-Louis.
On 24 May, students took the street in Dakar, Saint-Louis, Ziguinchor, Thies and Babey to claim for justice as to the killing of a student on 15 May in Saint-Louis.
On 24 May, students took the street in Dakar, Saint-Louis, Ziguinchor, Thies and Babey to claim for justice as to the killing of a student on 15 May in Saint-Louis.
On 24 May, the Senegalese army and armed robbers clashed in Samick, Boutoupacamacounda. A baby was killed by a lost bullet.
On 6 June, Orange Money workers in Ziguinchor organised a sit-in in front of the Sonatel building.
On 28 June, some armed men attacked a trader in Baghagha, Ziguinchor, before seizing some cattle and looting several shops.
On 30 June, Mboro, Thies, people went to the street to protest the exploitation of gold in the area.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Looting: On 6 July, 20 MFDC men entered Djibanar village, Goudomp, firing shots in the air and seizing 30 cattle heads.
On July 10, members of the Fulani community in Senegal staged a protest in Dakar, denouncing violence targeting the Fulani in neighbouring Mali. [size=dozens]
On 11 July, handicap defenders marched in Dakar to denounce discrimination and the non-enforcement of the relevant law.
On 13 July, the FNR supporters demonstrated in Dakar to support Karim Wade.
On 15 July, merchants protested in Mbour against a visit of national cadres of Unacois/Jappo to the city and called for an improvement of the local economy.
On 17 July, clashes between the Senegalese army and unidentified assailants reportedly took place in Djibanar, leading to 6 dead. The mayor of Dijabanar denies that the event took place.
On 18 July, Greenpeace protested outside of the National Agency of Maritime Affairs in Dakar to call for the publication of results regarding environmental adjustments in industrial fishing vessels.

On September 4, some demonstrators supporters of FNR organized a non-authorized protest before the Interior Ministry in Dakar. Senegalese police blocked the protest by using tear gas and arresting several protesters. The FRN took the initiative of this rally for the ""confirmation of candidacies"" to the 2019 presidential elections of Karim Wade and Khalifa Ababacar Sall, two opposition leaders whose presentation at this poll is threatened by court decisions

On September 14th, residents of localities along the Senegal River gathered in Kanel to demand better road and sanitary infrastructure and the deployment of medical units. The march was organized by the ""Dande Mayo Emergent Movement"".
In the night between Oct 11 and 12, 89 were arrested in Guediawaye district for various offenses as part of the fight against insecurity ""in all its forms"".
On Oct 16, people demonstrated to demand the closure of the Auchan distribution chain in Dakar.
""A female security guard at an INGO office was attacked by unidentified armed assailants and suffered knife injuries to her head and face.""
On Nov 5, dozens of teachers marched in Matam (north) to protest the delays in the work of the Higher Institute of Vocational Education (ISEP).

On Nov 8, several NGOs organized a global march to demand the release of blogger Mohamed Mkhaitir detained in jail in Mauritania since 2014, the court sentenced the 35-year-old man to death for publishing an article on his blog denouncing the discrimination against blacksmiths, caste to which he belongs.
On Nov 12, a group of armed men killed the major of Dombondir and his nephew in Dombondir.
On Nov 15, shepherd was killed by shooting by an unknown armed group in Kousi, a village located in the commune of Mangaroungou, department of Goudomp.
On Nov 22, students walked in Thies to demand the reopening of university restaurants, which have closed pending the settlement of a debt of one billion CFA francs the state.
Young coalition supporters threw stones at a Republican Youth Gathering coordinator during the inauguration of the candidate Macky Sall by the youth of Benno bokk yaakaar on 25 Nov 2018 in Dakar.
On 29 Nov 2018, FNR supporters held a march in Dakar demanding electoral process transparency.
On 1 Dec 2018, FNR youth members staged a demonstration in front of the Cote d'Ivoire embassy in Dakar, denouncing President Alassane Ouattara's alleged interference in Senegalese political affairs.
On Dec 15, inhabitants from Guediawaye, among which Alliance Sauver le Senegal Movement militants, took the streets to demand the construction of cemeteries in the town.
On Dec 16, a group of people marched to protest against land grabbing by neighbouring villages, notably Mlomp and Oukout. They chanted slogan and demanded the resignation of the Prefect.

On Dec 17, a group of people, notably from the Collectif des habitants des entites traditionnelles d'Oussouye, de Calobone et d'Ekink, protested in Oussouye against expropriation of their lands by neighbouring cities and to demand the extension of their town.

On Dec 19, in Dakar, political leaders Ousmane Sonko and Barthelemy Dias organized a protest to raise awareness on the opening of Khalifa Ababacar Sall trial on Dec 20. The crowd allegedly clashed with Police Forces, who used teargas to disperse them.

column7: AG: And Gueussum; UNSAS: National Union of Autonomous Syndicates of Senegal; Health Workers (Senegal)
column17: On Dec 20, social and health workers from And Gueusseum and UNSAS syndicates marched to demand the respect of agreements signed with the State and to protest against the government decision to deduct part of their salaries as a result of their previous strikes.
On Dec 26, in Diourbel, a group of people marched to demand the continuation of Ndoumbe Diop's market renovation, which was destroyed by a fire a year ago.

column7: FNR: National Resistance Front; PDS: Senegalese Democratic Party; GP: Grand Party
column17: On Dec 28, in Dakar, following FNR's call, between 2,000 and 3,000 militants from 10 different political parties opposed to the government, notably from PDS and GP parties, marched to demand future democratic and free presidential elections in February 2019. Some protesters were also calling for the release of political prisoners, notably Khalifa Sall.
On Jan 2 (or before), a group of inhabitants from Khare village close to Richard-Toll in Dagana department, marched to protest against poor living conditions and lack of infrastructures.
On Jan 5, 3 APR militants clashed with 2 other APR militants for political reasons (unclear), several of them were injured. They were reportedly arrested by Police forces.
On Jan 9, a group of militants opposed to the regime, led by Bougane Gueye Dany, protested against the organization of the national elections, wearing red gilets, in Place de la Nation, Dakar.
On Jan 11, in Dakar, FNR militants marched to protest against lack of transparency regarding the elections process.

On Jan 12, in Dakar, a group of militants from different political parties opposed to the government protested against the organization of the upcoming national elections, after the invalidation of 20 candidates by the Constitutional Council.
On Jan 13, in Guediawaye, militants supporting Presidential candidate Malick Gakou protesting against the nullification of his candidacy clashed with Police Forces.

On Jan 14, in Dakar, Rond-Point JVC, a group of Taxawu militants supporting Khalifa Sall protested against the nullification of his candidacy at the national elections. They clashed with police forces, throwing stones at them, and burned tires on the roads. Police Forces used teargast against protesters and damaged Taxawu Senegal sis headquarter. An unknown number was injured and several militants arrested.

column7: APR: Alliance for the Republic; Police Forces of Senegal (2012-)
column17: On Jan 14, in Rufisque, a group of Rabonnir Rufisque militants protested against the damages caused by the Regional Express Train (Train Express Regional) project, wearing red tee shirts. They threw stones at Dakar Dem Dikk buses. A group of APR militants physically assaulted them, throwing stones. Police Forces interfered, using teargas. One journalist was assaulted by APR militants while he was filming a militant allegedly taking out a gun.
On Jan 14 in the evening and Jan 15 in the morning, in Saint Louis, students from Gaston Berger University blocked the National Road 2, to protest against the delay of scholarships payment.

On Jan 15, in Dakar, C25 militants opposed to the government, barricaded the VDN road, and damaged ARP headquarter and Dakar Dem Dikk buses, protesting against the nullification of 25 candidacies by the Constitutional Council. Police Forces intervened using teargas.
On 20 January, 2019, residents of Ndaldagou, Potou and Gabar 2 villages in Louga marched to protest the selling of their lands.

column9: PASTEF: Patriots of Senegal for Work, Ethics and Fraternity
column17: On 23 January, 2019, armed men ransacked the headquarters of the PASTEF presidential candidate Ousmane Sonko in Yoff with axes and machetes.
On 30 January, 2019, youth in Dakar gathered to march in opposition to the current regime chanting slogans such as ""transparency in elections"" and ""liberate the youth.""
On 31 January, 2019, youth in the suburbs of Pikine and Guediawaye in Dakar took part in a march to mobilize the opposition.
On 02 February, 2019, villagers in Kounayang Mandingue held a protest against the lack of social services offered in their villages

On or around 12 February, 2019, armed supporters of Macky Sall (BBY) and Issa Sall (PUR) clashed in Tambacounda, leaving two people dead. Police arrested 24 after the events, mainly members of Issa Sall's security guard.

On or around 12 February, 2019, BBY supporters assaulted a minibus transporting journalists responsible for following the opposition PUR candidate's convoy in Tambacounda and wounded eight of the journalists.

On 21 February, 2019, Senegalese police forces seized a cache of weapons including firearms, machetes, explosives and detonators in the cities of Kedougou and Tambacounda and arrested 21 ""evildoers.""

On 21 February, 2019, Senegalese police forces seized a cache of weapons including firearms, machetes, explosives and detonators in the cities of Kedougou and Tambacounda and arrested 21 ""evildoers.""

On 26 February, 2019, youth protested the election results in front of the Radiodiffusion television national (RTS) headquarters in Dakar. They were met with grenades of tear gas by police forces. [size=no report]
On or around 28 February, 2019, women gathered in Dakar improvising a ""concert of pots and pans"" to protest the results of the recent elections. [size=no report]
On 28 February, 2019, civilians gathered in Dakar at the Leopold Sedar Senghor avenue and held a demonstration throwing rocks, burning tires and vandalizing buidings. [size=no report]
On 19 March, 2019, high school students in Pikine held a demonstration demanded more peaceful study zones [size=no report].
On 15 April, 2019, protesters gathered in the streets of Barry Ndondol to demand better implementation of social housing [size= no report].
26 May. Demonstrators marched in Tambacounda, denouncing the increase in sexual assault and rape within the country. Most of the demonstrators were women. [size=100].
On 30 May, 2019, citizens gathered to protest against violence directed at women in Kebemer [size=no report].
On 31 May, 2019, citizens gathered to protest against violence directed at women in Saint Louis [size=no report].
On 13 June, 2019, women gathered in Sedhiou to protest against violence directed at women and children [size= no report].
On 21 June, 2019, civilians in Dakar protested against the recent scandal published by BBC about the president, Macky Sall's brother's ties to corruption [size= many].
On 27 June, 2019, health workers gathered in Dakar to protest and announce a strike against their employers, denouncing their low salaries [size= no report].
On 28 June, 2019, Senegalese police forces impeded protesters for gathering in Dakar to demand more transparency in the president's brother's affairs [size= no report].
On 02 August, 2019, citizens protested to demand the liberation of the activist Guy Marius Sagna [size= no report].
On or around 04 August, 2019, citizens protested to demand the liberation of the activist Guy Marius Sagna [size= no report].
On 22 September, 2019, 300 civilians gathered in Sedhiou to protest the cattle theft and to demand tighter security [size= 300].

On 26 September, 2019, residents of Sedhiou held a sit-in at the city headquarters to demand the release of a detained kankourang who was arrested on charges of assaulting a woman. They claim that his trial would be contrary to the costums of secrecy vis a vis the kankourang and the circumcision rituals. [size=no report].
On 07 October 2019, rioters shut the road leading to Saint Louis University with burning tires [size=50].
On 09 October 2019, train workers have stopped the trains leading to and from the capital, Dakar, to protest their delayed pay [size=no report].
On 25 October, 2019, students protested in Dakar against a delay in the disbursement of scholarship funds. Police responded with forces resulting in the injury of one student. [size=no report].

column9: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: On 27 October, 2019, gunmen opened fire on members of the separatist movement, Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance, killing at least two people and injuring two others.
On 04 November, 2019, students form the law school at the UCAD university in Dakar held a protest against financial mishandling in the university [size=no report].

On 05 November, 2019, students at a university in Bambey protested to mark an ongoing strike and to prevent a chemistry event from taking place. A number of scuffles took place between police forces and student protesters. [size=no report].

column7: Aar Li Nu Bokk; FDS: Democratic Forces of Senegal; SNP: Senegal Our Priority
column17: On 29 November 2019, Aar Li Nu Bokk members and members of parties protested at the presidential palace in Dakar against electricity prices. [size=no report].

column16: Le Quotidien (Senegal); EnQuete Plus; Sud Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: On or around 02 December 2019, a prominent party figure was arrested by police forces in Dakar for political reasons and supporters of the party have planned a protest in response.
On 04 December 2019, party members of Aar Li No Bokk protested at the presidential palace in Dakar to demand the release of political detainees arrested earlier in the week. [size=no report]
On 06 December 2019, students protested in Dakar against the university for a delay in scholarship disbursement and police forces were present to keep the order. [size=no report]
On 09 December 2019, women protested in Guediawaye against sexual violence. [size=hundreds]
On 10 December 2019, citizens protested in Dakar to commemorate the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. [size=no report]
On 11 December 2019, fishermen protested in Fas Boye against the destruction of three fishing canoes by a foreign vessel. [size=no report]

On 11 December 2019, citizens held a sit-in in front of a prison in Dakar to protest against the release of several detainees they claim were arrested unlawfully. During the protest four individuals were arrested. [size=at least 4).

column7: FNR: National Resistance Front; Aar Li Nu Bokk
column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Sen360; EnQuete Plus; Le Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: On 13 December 2019, members of several political parties including the National Resistance Front and Aar Li Nu Bokk gathered in Dakar to protest against the increasing electricity prices and the imprisonment of several activists. [size=2 million].

column16: Sud Quotidien (Senegal); WalfNet; Le Quotidien (Senegal); EnQuete Plus
column17: On 20 December 2019, police forces deployed tear gas on journalists covering a protest in Dakar. The protesters were demonstrating against rising prices of electricity. More than 20 people were arrested. [size=at least 20]
On 28 December 2019, residents of Diourbel protested to demand that the main road be paved. [size=no report]
On 01 January 2020, residents of Madina Wandifa protested against the lack of potable water. [size=hundreds]
On 03 January 2020, members following the movement Noo Lank denouncing the increase in electricity prices, protested in Dakar. [size=no report]
On 10 January 2020, citizens protested in Diourbel against the recent increase in electricity prices and to demand the liberation of three protesters from their movement. [size=no report]

column16: EnQuete Plus; Sud Quotidien (Senegal); RFI; Le Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: On 10 January 2020, citizens protested in Dakar against the recent increase in electricity prices and to demand the liberation of three protesters from their movement. [size=no report]
On 15 January 2020, five police officers and two students were injured in clashes on a campus in Bambey, after students demonstrated over a desire to hold a general assembly. [size=dozens]
On 17 January 2020, citizens from Dandemayo gathered in Dakar to protest against the lack of paved roads, electricity and potable water in their locality. [size=no report]
On 24 January 2020, workers from RTS protested in Dakar to demand the resignation of the company's leadership. [size=no report].

column16: Sud Quotidien (Senegal); Le Quotidien (Senegal); WalfNet; EnQuete Plus
column17: On 31 January 2020, supporters of Guy Marius Sagna and the Noo Lank movement protested in in Medina (Dakar) to demand the liberation of the figure. [size=no report]

On 04 February 2020, angry fishermen demonstrated in Saint Louis to call on their government authorities to help in the crisis with Mauritania over water rights. Rioters put fire to tires on some streets and clashed with police forces resulting in injuries to 20 or more people. [size=no report]
On 12 February 2020, at least 8 youths protested in Fatick (Fatick) over the results of a friend's autopsy. [size=at least 8]

On 14 Feb. 2020, a group of Senegalese transporters attacked a bus of the Gambia Transport Company in Karang border town, Toubacouta subdivision (Foundiougne, Fatick), saying that only one bus was authorized to travel from Banjul to Dakar everyday. The incident resulted in the border being shortly closed. [size=no report]

column16: Le Quotidien (Senegal); Agence de Presse Senegalaise
column17: On 15 Feb. 2020, hundreds of people staged a protest in Notto Diobass town, in Thies subdivision (Keur Moussa, Thies) against the lack of drinking water. [size=hundreds]
On 20 Feb. 2020 (or around), the police forces arrested 196 people during a security operation in Touba town (Missirah, Tambacounda).

On 22 Feb. 2020, a group of teachers from a coalition of seven teachers' unions staged a protest in Thies town (Keur Moussa, Thies) to demand the enforcement of an agreement they signed with the authorities since 2018 about the taxation of their salary arrears, among other issues. [size=no report]

On 25 Feb. 2020 (or around), a group of students demonstrated in Kaffrine town, Keur Mboucki subdivision (Birkelane, Kaffrine) against their poor study conditions, and the lack of teachers. They erected barricades and burnt tires on the road. The police forces intervened and fired tear gas to disperse them. [size=no report]

column16: Sud Quotidien (Senegal); Sen360; Agence de Presse Senegalaise; RFI
column17: On 27 Feb. 2020, members and supporters of the Noo Lank movement demonstrated in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar), against increases to the price of electricity, and to demand the liberation of one of its leaders who was arrested during a previous demonstration. [size=no report]

On 27 Feb. 2020, the population of Diokoul neighbourhood of Rufisque town (Rufisque, Dakar) demonstrated to demand that their neighbourhood be taken into account in the ongoing installation of a water sewerage system. [size=no report]

column7: SAEMSS: Autonomous Union of Middle and Secondary Teachers of Senegal; Teachers (Senegal)
column17: On 5 March 2020, a group of teachers of the SAEMSS teachers union demonstrated in Thies town (Keur Moussa, Thies) against the 'increasing precariousness' of their jobs. [size=no report]

On 9 March 2020, a group of students who recently earned they high school degree demonstrated in Dakar town (Dakar Plateau, Dakar) to denounce the fact that there were not yet oriented to universities. [size=no report]

On 17 March 2020, Gendarmerie forces intervened to disperse a gathering of around 80 people during a traditional ceremony in Goudomp town (Djibanar, Goudomp, Sedhiou), in application of government measures against the propagation of coronavirus. This resulted in a clashes with the organizers who didn't want to leave. [size=around 80]

column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; AFP; WalfNet; Reuters
column17: On 23 March 2020, the Government of Senegal declared a state of emergency to combat the coronavirus, banning gatherings and instituting a curfew from 8 p.m to 6 a.m.

column16: AFP; Le Quotidien (Senegal); WalfNet; Agence de Presse Senegalaise
column17: On 25 March 2020 (or around), the police forces reportedly beat up several people, including health workers, in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar), accused of violating the curfew measure instituted to combat the spread of the coronavirus.

On 22 April 2020, Mauritanians demonstrated in Rosso Senegal village, in Ndiaye subdivision (Dagana, Saint Louis) demanding the release of 6 of their countrymen arrested by the Senegalese police. [size=no report]

On 7 May 2020, villagers demonstrated in Thor village, Thies subdivision (Keur Moussa, Thies) against the decision of authorities to quarantine 20 suspected coronavirus cases. They threw stones at the local response centre and clashed with the military forces who intervened to disperse them. [size=no report]
Around 12 May 2020 (as reported), two groups of fishermen clashed in Yarakh neighbourhood of Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar) over the use of a controversial fishing technique. [size=no report]

column8: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: Around 13 May 2020, military forces engaged in a firefight with MFDC fighters in the Bissine area (Niaguis, Ziguinchor). No fatality and/or casualty reported.

column16: EnQuete Plus; Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Le Quotidien (Senegal)
column17: On 20 May 2020, about a hundred 'Jakarta' (taxi bike) drivers demonstrated in Tambacounda town (Katakel, Kaffrine) to demand authorisation to restart activities after authorities lifted a circulation restriction for taxi drivers to combat the coronavirus. The police forces fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, and they replied by erecting barricades and burning tires on several roads. 7 people were briefly arrested. [size=about a hundred]

column8: Military Forces of Senegal (2012-) Fire Fighter Corps
column17: On 26 May 2020, residents threw stones at fire fighters and damaged their vehicle in the Malika neighbourhood of Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar) to prevent them from burying one person deceased of the coronavirus in their cemetery. 4 people were arrested. [size=at least 4]

On 28 May 2020, residents threw stones at Red Cross volunteers in the Diamaguene-Sicap Mbao neighbourhood of Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar) to prevent them from burying one person deceased of the coronavirus in the local cemetery. 3 volunteers were injured. [size=no report]

column16: 2sTV; Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Sen360; Le Quotidien (Senegal); EnQuete Plus; AFP
column17: On 30 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Cap Skirring in Cabrousse subdivision (Oussouye, Ziguinchor) against the lack of running water. They burnt tires on the roads. The gendarmerie forces fired tear gas and live ammunition to disperse them, to which they replied with stones. 3 demonstrators and 3 gendarmes were severely injured. 16 people were also arrested. [size=at least 16]

column16: 2sTV; Le Quotidien (Senegal); Agence de Presse Senegalaise
column17: On 2 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Diourbel town (Diourbel) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. They reportedly clashed with security forces (assumed Police Forces). 2 demonstrators were arrested. [size=no report]

column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Le Quotidien (Senegal); 2sTV; Sud Quotidien (Senegal); AFP
column17: On 2 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Mbacke town (Mbacke) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. They attacked and partly damaged the local office of the Senelec national electricity company as well a local radio station, and burnt an ambulance. The security forces (assumed Police Forces) intervened and arrested 38 demonstrators. [size=at least 38]
On 2 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Ndiassane town (Tivaouane, Thies) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. [size=no report]

On 2 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Tambacounda town (Koussanar, Tambacounda) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. They clashed with the security forces (assumed Police Forces). 5 demonstrators were arrested. [size=at least 5]

On 2 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Thies town (Keur Moussa, Thies) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. They reportedly clashed with security forces (assumed Police Forces) who were trying to disperse them. [size=no report]
On 2 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Tivaouane town (Tivaouane, Thies) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. [size=no report]

column16: Reuters; Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Le Quotidien (Senegal); 2sTV; AFP
column17: On 2 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Touba town (Mbacke, Diourbel) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. They burnt tires on the public square, and threw stones at the police forces who replied with tears gas. 60 demonstrators were arrested. [size=at least 60]

column16: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; 2sTV; AFP; Reuters
column17: On 3 June 2020, residents demonstrated in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar) against the prolonged counter coronavirus curfew measure. They threw stones at the police forces who replied with tear gas. [size=no report]
On 3 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Kaolack town (Koumbal, Kaolack) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. [size=no report]

On 3 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Nioro du Rip town (Nioro du Rip, Kaolack) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. [size=no report]

On 3 June 2020, transporters demonstrated for the second day in a row in Touba town (Mbacke, Diourbel) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. They burnt three intervention vehicles of the police and an ambulance, and threw stones at the local office of the Senelec national electricity company. 29 demonstrators were arrested. [size=at least 29]

On 3 June 2020, transporters demonstrated in Kaffrine town (Birkelane, Kaffrine) against the prolonged restriction of their activity in the context of anti coronavirus state measures. [size=no report]

On 5 June 2020, unidentified individuals opened fire on a group of young men in Bilass village, near Boutoupa Camaracounda (Niaguis, Ziguinchor), injuring 3 of them. The reason of the attack is unclear.

column16: Sud Quotidien (Senegal); Agence de Presse Senegalaise
column17: On 6 June 2020, a landmine exploded in Mbissine-Albondy village, Adeane subdivision (Adeane, Ziguinchor), injuring 3 soldiers. The army says this was an accident while other sources say the mine might have been planted by an armed group as the military recently started an operation in the area.

On 8 June 2020, Mauritanian citizens stranded in Senegal because of the border closure after the coronavirus outbreak, demonstrated in Rosso Senegal border town (Dagana, Saint Louis), calling on the Mauritanian authorities to allow them to cross the border. [size=no report]

On 9 June 2020, about 50 people demonstrated in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar) in support of the Black Lives Matter movement and to denounce racism in the U.S. after the killing of George Floyd. [size= about 50]

On 13 June 2020, a landmine planted by an unknown group exploded, targeting a military vehicle near Lefeu village (Bignona, Ziguinchor), injuring 8 soldiers. The army recently started a security operation in the area.

column16: Reuters; 2sTV; WalfNet; EnQuete Plus; AFP; Sen360; State TV News (Senegal); Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Le Quotidien (Senegal); PANAPRESS; Sud Quotidien (Senegal)
