column17: On 15 June 2020, a landmine planted by an unknown group exploded, targeting a military vehicle on the road from Mbissine to Diagnon villages in the Niaguis region (Niaguis, Ziguinchor), killing 2 soldiers, and injuring 4 others. The army recently started a repatriation operation for the population of the area who fled the 90s Casamance secessionist conflict.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: On 16 June 2020, military forces engaged in a gun battle with MFDC fighters in Singhere Diola village, near Bissine (Niaguis, Zinguinchor), as the MFDC was opposing to the reinstallation of the population in the area. The army recently started a repatriation operation of the population of the area who fled the 90s Casamance secessionist conflict. No fatality and/or casualty reported.

On 18 June 2020, residents demonstrated in Diourbel town (Diourbel, Diourbel) in support of members of families who refused to be quarantined after their relatives died from the coronavirus. They clashed with police forces who fired tear gas to disperse them, and arrested 6 people. [size=at least 6]

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: On 19 June 2020, military forces engaged in gun battle with MFDC fighters in Singhere Diola and Bissine villages (Niaguis, Zinguinchor). The army recently started a repatriation operation of the population of the area who fled the 90s Casamance secessionist conflict. No fatality and/or casualty reported.

column6: MFDC: Movement of Democratic Forces of Casamance
column17: On 19 June 2020, military forces engaged in a gun battle with MFDC fighters in Singhere Diola and Bissine villages (Niaguis, Zinguinchor). The army recently started a repatriation operation of the population of the area who fled the 90s Casamance secessionist conflict. No fatality and/or casualty reported.

On 22 June 2020, residents demonstrated in Koumpentoum town (Koumpentoum, Tambacounda) against a lack of running water. They burnt tires and clashed with the gendarmerie forces who attempted to disperse them. One gendarme was severely injured, and several demonstrators arrested. [size=at least several]

On 22 June 2020, the owners of 253 houses previously demolished in a disputed piece of land held a collective hunger strike on the disputed area in the Gadaye neighbourhood of Dakar city (Dakar-Plateau, Dakar). The police forces fired tear gas to disperse them resulting in 7 people injured. They also arrested 11. [size=at least 11]

Around 5 July 2020, Guineans living in Senegal demonstrated in front of the Guinean Embassy in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar) to demand their repatriation due to the coronavirus crisis. [size=no report]

On 19 July 2020, the members of two families clashed in Rufisque town (Rufisque, Dakar) over a land dispute. One person was stabbed to death, and another sustained injuries. The gendarmerie forces arrested one person.

On 28 July 2020, a group of traders attacked the office of Dakar Dem Dikk national transport company and destroyed 2 buses in Keur Massar town (Pikine, Dakar), for an unknown reason. Several were arrested. [size=at least several]

On 28 July 2020, a group of traders attacked the office of Dakar Dem Dikk national transport company and destroyed 2 buses in Keur Massar town (Pikine, Dakar), for an unknown reason. Several were arrested. [size=at least several]

column16: 2sTV; WalfNet; Sen360; Agence de Presse Senegalaise; AFP; RFI
column17: On 3 August 2020, supporters of a Muslim leader attacked the office of a local newspaper in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar), after the newspaper published information saying that their leader contracted the coronavirus. They damaged the office of the Editor-in-Chief, as well as equipment, including seven computers and a TV set. Six suspects were reportedly arrested in connection with that incident. [size=at least 6]

On 5 August 2020, residents demonstrated in Matam town (Ogo, Matam) to demand that mining companies comply with the national mining code as well as their social responsibility. The Gendarmerie tried to disperse them using tear gas, but the demonstrators continued their march. [size=no report]

On 9 August 2020, a group of youths attacked the gendarmerie post of Aroundou neighbourhood of Ballou town (Bakel, Tambacounda), injuring 2 gendarmes. The confrontation started after the gendarmes disrupted a football play and arrested players for reportedly violating the counter coronavirus State of Emergency. 13 people were arrested in connection with that event. [size=at least 13]

On 14 August 2020, a fistfight escalated between the supporters of two Muslim leaders in Janatou Mahwa neighbourhood of Touba town (Mbacke, Diourbel). Several people were injured, and several others arrested. It is unclear what prompted the dispute. [size=at least several]

Around 23 August 2020 (as reported), a crowd of suspected LGBT people demonstrated in front of the CEDEPS office in Nioro du Rip town (Nioro du Rip, Kaolack) to get HIV tests. The gendarmerie forces intervened to disperse them. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2020, a violent confrontation escalated between residents and the police and gendarmerie forces in Jaxaay neighbourhood of Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar), with residents burning tires on the road. The reason of the clashes was not reported. [size=no report]

On 14 September 2020, unidentified individuals burnt the city hall down in Kotiari Naoude village (Goudiry, Tambacounda). The reason for the attack was not reported. No fatality and/or casualty reported.

column16: Le Quotidien (Senegal); Agence de Presse Senegalaise
column17: On 15 September 2020, the military forces established a new base in Nemanding village, around Fatick town (Tattaguine, Fatick).

column9: PDS: Senegalese Democratic Party; Women (Senegal); Government of Senegal (2012-)
column17: On 21 September 2020, unidentified individuals attacked and injured a female PDS party MP in Pikine town (Pikine, Dakar). This happened after the victim called on the government to help the vulnerable population of Guinaw-Rails Nord neighbourhood, during a TV show. [size=no report]
On 22 September 2020, the military forces established a base in Nguidile town (Mbediene, Louga).

Around 30 September 2020 (overnight), a group of youths demonstrated in Maka Kolibantang town (Koussanar, Tambacounda) against the decision of the authorities to ban a festival. They threw stones at the houses of the sub-prefect and the deputy sub-prefect. The security forces (assumed Police Forces) arrested 5. [size=no report]

On 1 October 2020, police officers beat up a female journalist and broke her equipment as she was recording the arrest of an activist in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar). 4 police officers were arrested in relation to that incident.

On 4 October 2020, several residents demonstrated in Paroumba town (Velingara, Kolda) to demand better life conditions, especially better access to water, electricity and health services. [size=several]
On 10 October 2020, residents demonstrated in Ranerou town (Ranerou-Ferlo, Matam) against the illegal trade of alcohol in Matam region. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, residents demonstrated in Tivaouane Peulh neighborhood of Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar) against the demolition of their houses. They reportedly clashed with the security forces (assumed Police Forces). 6 demonstrators were arrested. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, supporters of two rival leaders of the PDS (opposition) party engaged in a fist fight during a PDS rally in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar). The reason of the incident remains unclear. One female journalist was beaten up and lost two fingers. [size=no report]
On 17 October 2020, residents demonstrated in Dangalma village (Bambey, Diourbel) against the mismanagement of rural water supply facilities by Aquatech water and sanitation Company. [size=no report]
On 17 October 2020, the security forces (assumed Police Forces) arrested 25 homosexual persons during a wedding ceremony in Mbao neighborhood of Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar).
On 17 October 2020, residents demonstrated in Madina Wandifa town (Bounkiling, Sedhiou), demanding the cancellation of the 2010 subdivision of the commune's lands. [size=no report]
On 18 October 2020, members of President Yeyoo Fuuta movement demonstrated in Ouro Sogui town (Ogo, Matam) to express several development concerns about the Fouta region. [size=no report]

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On 21 October 2020, supporters of the UFDG Guinean opposition party demonstrated in front of the Guinean Embassy in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar) after the announcement of the partial results of the presidential election according to which incumbent president Alpha Conde was winning the polls. They claimed the victory of their party's leader. The police forces fired tear gas to disperse them, injuring at least 2. [size=no report]
Arrests: Police detain a journalist who recently published a politically disagreeable article.
18 April. SLPP supporters of Mr Usman Boie Kamara and SLPP supporters of Rt. Gen. Maada Bion clashed before the party convention; location not specified, but most likely in or near Freetown.
Two ethnic groups clash over a 10-acre plot of land over several days. No report of causalities.

A journalist is stabbed and killed by an armed group. Police make three arrests several days later in connection to the killing. The group that attacked the reporter believed his writing was biased against them.

A journalist is stabbed and killed by an armed group. Police make three arrests several days later in connection to the killing. The group that attacked the reporter believed his writing was biased against them.

column9: Civilians (Sierra Leone); APC: All Peoples Congress
column17: 09 September. Political protesters pelted stones at a caravan of a presidential candidate, causing injuries and burn down APC buildings. Riot police fired teargas and shot live bullets into the air in an effort to quell the protests. In the following days the local government banned street protests in an effort to quell the violence.

Political protesters pelted stones at a caravan of a presidential candidate, causing injuries. Riot police fired teargas and shot live bullets into the air in an effort to quell the protests. In the following days the local government banned street protests in an effort to quell the violence.
Two children died in a grenade explosion after they found the device, a remnant of the countries civil war, while searching for scrap metal in the north.
Arrests: Police arrest and charge 25 students with cultism.

Abdul Karim Fonti Kabia, the Executive editor of a Freetown-based privately-owned Sierra Leone News Hunters (ARIOBGO) newspaper, was on November 30, 2011 violently assaulted by two pastors of the Baptist Convention Church. The attack was allegedly instigated by Reverend Darlington Morrison, the leader of the church, whom the newspaper had accused of duping a businesswoman.
Security Measures: The government lifts a ban of public rallies and protests that was implemented three months ago following a clash.
A violent gang assaults leading members of an opposition political party at their headquarters.

On 15 April, Sierra Leonean employees at the African Minerals Limited in Bumbuna initiated a public demonstration to protest their working conditions and remuneration, blocking the main roads leading to the town.
On 16 April, Sierra Leonean employees at the African Minerals Limited in Bumbuna gathered in front of the courthouse to protest their working conditions and remuneration.

Property destruction: On 17 April, the police entered the main Bumbuna marketplace in reprisal for the previous day demonstrations and fired tear gas and live ammunitions into the air. Several female traders reported that the police also looted or destroyed their markets stalls.
On 18 April, police opened fire on people marching towards the police station to protest police misconduct, wounding 11 and killing 1

column7: SLCRC: Sierra Leone Civil Rights Coalition
column17: Youths clashed with the police who fired tear gas canisters to disperse protests over the killing on Tuesday of two youths the police mistakenly took for armed robbers.
Families of the victims of the 1992 National Provisional Ruling Council (NPRC) killing protest government inaction in inquiry of their deaths.
A student protest of the expulsion of 30 students turns violent, tires burned. No causalities reported, nor property damage.
Witnesses see police assault journalists and take their equipment. The journalists were covering a military protest by former soldiers.
Looting: The National Headquarters of the United Democratic Movement (UDM) along Pademba Road in Freetown, was on Monday 13th August 2012 ransacked by unknown persons.

Supporters of the opposition SLPP went on a violent rampage, attacking the homes of supporters of the ruling APC. The attacks followed a campaign rally staged in the area. Molotov cocktails were used in the attacks. Ten wounded.

column8: PMDC: Peoples Movement for Democratic Change
column17: Supporters of the SLPP and the PMDC, a party splintered from the SLPP clash in Bo ahead of an election.

On 2 November 2012, fighting took place between supporters of the opposition party, SLPP, and the ruling party, APC, in Kenema. More than five people were injured whilst the residence of the APC parliamentary candidate for Constituency 10 was attacked.
On 16 December, workers at the Koidu Holdings diamond mine held a sit-down at the mine over bonuses and work conditions.
On 18 December, police responded by firing tear gas and gunshots to people throwing stones at the vehicle of the Minster of Mines. Police killed two people and seriously injured one woman.
A police officer stabs a civilian to death following a funeral. The violence is believe to be linked to a disagreement over the use of a trinket.

Supporters of the recently electorially defeated SLPP protest, causing road obstructions near the Law Courts Building in Freetown. The protesters are upset that their political rivals and election day victors, the All People's Congress, are refusing to hear a court case they favour.

column9: PMDC: Peoples Movement for Democratic Change
column17: Arrests: Charles Francis Margai, the leader of the opposition PMDC is arrested for ""making statements to undermine state security.""

column9: SLPP: Sierra Leone Peoples Party; Women (Sierra Leone)
column17: Members of the Po-a-Pa faction of the SLPP assault a group of SLPP women who did not support their orthodoxy.
Vigilante mob beats suspected thief to death
Women stage protest against rape in Sierra Leone
Two rival gangs fought each other. 2 youth died.
After Saturdays by-election, youth barricaded roads and intimidated people who were viewed as voting against their candidate. Police intervened.
After an escalation in tension between youth and students, police shot at the crowd, killing one student.
Mrs.Sampa Fullah died in hospital after being beaten by police officers in connection with an incident with another police officer, Constable Kamara, who was an in-law of hers
Paramount Chief Jonathan Tucker led an attack on a chiefdom administrative clerk with ""thugs"" including his relatives
Relatives of Pa Morlai Kamara attacked John Coker and his men with machetes when they were on land they had bought from Tabitha Venn, but the ownership of which is disputed by Kamara; 2 wounded
Aspirant to the presidency of the Sierra Leone Dock Workers Union verbally and physically attacked by dockworkers opposed to his candidacy

15 landowners were arrested after blocking SOCFIN vehicles, machinery and workers from accessing the main road into the Sahn Malen chiefdom; they were protesting against the terms of the lease agreement for land in the chiefdom

Twenty people were arrested and two police officers injured during a riot at the Plam Oil Production project in Mattru Jong, after stakeholders incited people against a government takeover of the project
A music producer was attacked by about seven men due to his songs about mineral exploitation, corruption and tribalism.
A second music producer who wrote songs about corruption and tribalism was attacked by three men due to his songs about mineral exploitation, corruption and tribalism.
Human rights activists across West Africa held protests on the 20th anniversary of President Yahya Jammehs seizure of power in Gambia to raise awareness of Gambias human rights situation.

Thousands of protesters marched on the main Ebola hospital in Kenema and threatened to burn it down and remove the patients after a rumour spread about ""cannabalistic rituals"" occurring there; police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd, and allegedly hit a young boy in the leg with a bullet.
Riots in Sierra Leone which prevent health workers from trying to bury Ebola victims.

column9: Health Workers (Sierra Leone); Police Forces of Sierra Leone (2005-)
column17: Health workers burying Ebola victims were attacked by youths in the village of Matainkay, 20km east of Freetown. Attack occurred on the second of a three-day Ebola lockdown in the country.

Hundreds took to the streets of Makeni to mistakenly celebrate the end of Ebola after hearing that suspected Ebola victims were released from a holding centre with negative lab test results. Police dispersed the crowd and placed a dusk-til-dawn curfew on residents No serious injuries reported.

Rioters in Aberdeen neighborhood of Freetown barricaded the street due to delays in removing the corpse of a suspected Ebola victim. Rioters threw stones at police; police fired tear gas and shot rounds from AK-47 rifles to disperse the crowd. No casual

A riot took place on Oct. 21 between youth and police in Koidu, after health workers were prevented from taking a blood sample from a 90-year-old woman suspected of having Ebola. Health workers called on police for protection from rioters. Youth wielded machetes and shovels, and attacked buildings, including Eastern Radio station. Riots resulted in two people dead and 10 injured. Identity of victims unavailable.
An ambulance carrying suspected Ebola patients crashed into a ditch in the northwestern district of Port Loko after a mob pelted it with stones. No injuries reported.

column9: Police Forces of Sierra Leone (2007-2018); Military Forces of Sierra Leone (2007-2018)
column17: In December, a riot involved a group of individuals - soldiers, police, and civilians - and an unknown gang. Both groups laid claim to the same land in Kaningo community in Lumley. A fracas began and injuries were reported.
Ebola health workers in Makeni staged a protest demanding hazard pay. Protest occurred alongside a ceremony for the release of 31 recovered Ebola patients.
Health workers at the PTS I Hastings Ebola Treatment Center in Freetown protested against non-payment of their December hazard incentives.

Rival supporters of candidates of the opposition Sierra Leone Peoples Party were apparently engaged in fisticuffs over where to mount portrait of former flag-bearer, Retired Brigadier Julius Maada Bio at their national headquarters on Wallace-Johnson Street in Freetown. It took the intervention of armed riot to disperse the groups.

Hundreds of supporters of the main opposition Sierra Leone Peoples Party (SLPP) yesterday stormed the precincts of the Connaught Hospital mortuary in central Freetown to foil what they described as attempts to bury the remains of their fallen comrade and National Publicity Secretary, Hon. Musa Tamba Sam, ""the Ebola way"". The supporters protested against the Ebola burial team taking charge of the burial of a man they considered as a ""senior statesman"", describing the move as total disrespect to the former opposition lawmaker and party spokesman. Both riot police and military officers were ordered to enforce calm at the scene of protest.

Despite a ban on public gathering and demonstration across Sierra Leone, a large group of women on Thursday, 25 March were seen openly demonstrating along St. John roundabout and Sanda Street, West of Freetown, in support of President Ernest Bai Koroma, according to reports. The women lined up along the street with brooms in their hands condemning any planned demonstration against the decision of President Koroma to relieve Vice President Samuel Sam-Sumana from office.

Some land owners and residents of Kathantha village in the Sella Limba Chiefdom, Bombali District, yesterday complained of ""terror threats"" allegedly being perpetrated against them by some officials of AMR Gold, a mining company operating in that part of the country. The protesters, who converged at the resident of one Simah Dumbuya in Freetown, made the claim in a two-page protest letter to the Minister of Mines and copied the President, Vice President, Attorney General, Inspector General of Police, Members of Parliament of Constituencies 35 and 36, Mines Engineer in Makeni and the District Council Chairman.

16 April. The Young Generation Wing of the opposition Sierra Leone Peoples Party (SLPP) Thursday demonstrated in front of the US Embassy in Freetown in protest against the sacking last month of the elected Vice President, Sam Sumana, calling it a blatant violation of the nations constitution. Police arrested 10 people.

Police in Bo attacked protesters following demonstrations on Monday against the sacking of Vice President Samuel Sam-Sumana. Riot police disrupted the demonstrations, beating up some protesters and arresting others. Demonstrators were seriously injured and required medical attention.

column7: SLPP: Sierra Leone Peoples Party; HRCSL: Human Rights Commission of Sierra Leone
column17: 27 April. Police in Kenema clashed with SLPP protesters following demonstrations on Monday against the sacking of Vice President Samuel Sam-Sumana. Riot police disrupted the demonstrations, beating up some protesters and arresting 15 others, including on HRC official. Demonstrators were seriously injured and required medical attention.
A civilian was tortured and beaten by 8 police personnel, which allegedly led to his death. The policemen were arraigned on charges of manslaughter on 8 September 2015.

Almost 200 protesters were at Youyi Building, Brookfields, protesting and demanding that officials of the Ministry of Health and Sanitation pay them for services provided. Street Life family was among the groups involved in the cleaning and sanitation for the re-opening of schools in the municipality

A huge crowd of youth under the nomenclature Street Life Family Organization (SLFO) demonstrated to show their support for President Ernest Bai Koroma as the court matter of former Vice President was underway.

A soldier belonging to the Operational Support Division (OSD) headquarters, who was accompanied by another soldier, shot dead a civilian at his home in Freetown on Sunday (June 14). Both soldiers have been arrested.

Unidentified gunmen reportedly attacked the house of the chief in Kathantha village. Five people were arrested by the police when it arrived on the scene and one person made a complaint that he was physically assaulted by police.

Unidentified gunmen reportedly attacked the house of the chief in Kathantha village. Five people were arrested by the police when it arrived on the scene and one person made a complaint that he was physically assaulted.

Hundreds of women and their partners representing various groups in the fight against sexual violence converged at Lumley Beach to mourn a murdered woman and appeal the Government to take action and bring those responsible to book.
13 rioters were arrested by police for attacking Calaba Town Police Station

Scores of women took streets in Kabala to mourn and protest what seemed to be a national trend - the killing and nude display of female corpse. They presented a position paper to authorities, expressing their concern regarding violence against women.
Over 30 parents with children attending Leone Preparatory School, on Friday staged a peaceful demonstration against the authority of the school because of the victimisation of some pupils.
Councillor Theresa Garba of Ward 05 in the Kailahun district presented a position paper on behalf of women and girls during a peaceful protest in the district against rape and sexual violence
Police forces violently dispersed Guinean civilians protesting in from of the Guinean embassy in Freetown over electoral card distributions. One person was severely injured and 20 arrested.
A group of war wounded gathered by the National Electoral Commission offices to protest that they were not being treated fairly and would like to have audience with the President.
28 November. APC supporters of Mayah Kaikai and SLPP supporters of incumbent local council chairman clash in Kailahun of Luawa ahead of bye elections.

Clashes occurred between the Ruling All Peoples Congress (APC) party and the main Opposition Sierra Leone Peoples Party (SLPP) ahead of Parliamentary bye-elections in Gaiama Sewafe in Kono District on 18 and 19 December. Supporters of both political parties sustained injuries during the two days fracas.
SLPP's Eastern Regional Chairman, Hon Philip Tondoneh's house was set on fire in clashes with the ruling APC on the eve of Parliamentary bye-elections in Nimikoro Chiefdom.

Clashes occurred between the Ruling All Peoples Congress (APC) party and the main Opposition Sierra Leone Peoples Party (SLPP) ahead of Parliamentary bye-elections in Gaiama Sewafe in Kono District on 18 and 19 December. Supporters of both political parties sustained injuries during the two days fracas.

Youth protested Ebola restrictions that have halted market activity in Barmoi Luma in Kambia district. At least eight people were injured, including with bullet wounds, as demonstrators allegedly burned down a police station and police fired tear gas to disperse them. 18 youths were arrested.

column7: Muslim Group (Sierra Leone); Christian Group (Sierra Leone)
column17: Sierra Leones Muslim and Christian leaders marched to parliament in Freetown to protest against a controversial draft law on abortion.
Angry youth pelted stones at Fire Forces for their alleged delay in responding to stress calls as a fire was engulfing a families house Siaka Stevens Street.
Students at Koyeima Government Secondary School in Valunia chiefdom vandalised properties belonging to the school and staff on the night of 2 February, to protest against bad treatment.

Members of the ruling All Peoples Congress allegedly attacked supporters of Sierra Leone Peoples Party ( SLPP) in Moyah village in Moyamba district following local council bye-elections, injuring five.

Hundreds of students from the Fourah Bay College, University of Sierra Leone staged a peaceful demonstration at State House demanding a change of the general administration due to some loopholes in the administrative system.
Over three hundred Police Support Staff stormed the Ministry of Finance asking for backlog claim on increases made to wages and other allowances since July 2011 to present
Pupils of Koidu Secondary School and Islamic Secondary Schools clashed in Koidu, Kono district, over alleged beatings, leaving 31 injured.

Hundreds of Ebola survivors protested in Freetown against perceived government inaction over their care. Police pushed back male protesters while women and children stood behind barricades waving placards and shouting slogans.
Hundreds of Ebola survivors protested in Makeni against perceived government inaction over their care.

Police arrested 29 members and supporters of the main opposition Sierra Leone People's Party (SLPP) for alleged unlawful procession, malicious damage and disorderly behaviour during the independence celebrations in Freetown. Police fired teargas to disperse the protesters. In August, six of the 29 were sentenced to six months' imprisonment, and one to nine months' imprisonment, on charges including unlawful procession and riotous conduct.
On 27th May 2016: Intra-Party violence within SLPP in kenema led to one person being stabbed.

Okada riders clashed with police officers at Model and Dwazark Junction in Freetown over the recent death of an okada rider, causing abrupt halt to normal traffic, schools and closure of some businesses within the area. The riders allegedly burnt tyres, spilled oil on the road, and threw stones and police cars. At least five people were arrested.

column7: APC: All Peoples Congress; Police Forces of Sierra Leone (2007-2018)
column17: July. APC and SLPP supporters clash in Kailahun of Luawa ahead of bye elections. Police intervene and search SLPP political candidate's home for weapons.

Members of a Poro mob chasing a representative of the Office of National Security clashed with soldiers at the Bonthe naval base, capturing a soldier and stealing weapons. Soldiers fired shots in the air, forcing the mob to flee. They came back the following day and clashed with the soldiers, leaving two members of the society dead while the Officer-in-charge and four other soldiers sustained severe injuries. Police later arrested and detained 14 people in connection with the event.

Members of a Poro mob chasing a representative of the Office of National Security clashed with soldiers at the Bonthe naval base, capturing a soldier and stealing weapons. Soldiers fired shots in the air, forcing the mob to flee. They came back the following day and clashed with the soldiers, leaving two members of the society dead while the Officer-in-charge and four other soldiers sustained severe injuries. Police later arrested and detained 14 people in connection with the event.

Thousands of people clashed with police and inspectors who had come to look for a consignment of imported rotten chicken buried at a Freetown rubbish dump after health officials deemed it unfit for consumption. Police used tear gas, stun grenades and rubber bullets to prevent people from removing the contaminated meat, and made 40 arrests. Police arrested an additional 25 people allegedly in possession of the rotten chicken in homes and major markets.

Youth in Koidu town, Kono district, staged violent protests after heavy rains washed off a bye-pass route preventing the flow of people and goods into and out of the city, blaming it on illegal mining activities.

column9: Government of Sierra Leone (2007-2018); APC: All Peoples Congress
column16: Concord Times; Xinhua; Amnesty International; AFP
column17: Security forces fired bullets into crowds of youths protesting against the relocation of a job training centre in Kabala, Koinadugu district, killing two and injuring at least 15 others. The youth activists set fire to the house of the police local unit commander and to the offices of the ruling APC party. 17 people were sent to trial for offences such as arson and riotous conduct and a curfew was imposed. The riot allegedly came as a result of the refusal of police to agree to demands made by angry youths to conduct peaceful demonstrations over the issue.

Youth demonstrated and burnt down three houses in Gbangbatoke, Bonthe District as the town chief was missing during his planned reinstatement, and clashed with police and military officers who were sent in to restore calm in the area. Two people were allegedly killed in the clashes, 11 injured, and nine were arrested.

Students at Fourah Bay College spread oil on the road heading to the campus and threw bottles and stones at passing cars to protest against an administrative decision to limit contestants in the student elections.

Hundreds of students protested in front of the law court building in Freetown, demanding the release of two of their colleagues arrested and charged a few days prior over inciting students to set ablaze vehicles in Freetown on social media.
Clashes between SLPP supporters in Bo over an alleged tearing of the constituency delegate list for the end November elections.
Sierra Leone's first Lieutenant General and former Chief of Defense Staff (CDS) was found dead at his residence in Simbo Town, Bo after unknown gunmen attacked.

A suspected private bodyguard of an SLPP flag bearer aspirant shot another SLPP supporter as she was participating in a protest in front of the Court in Freetown over irregularities in low level elections threatening the party's structure.
Unidentified attackers abducted a photo journalist who had been vocal about the political situation in the country at Hill station in Freetown.
Supporters of the Sierra Leone Peoples Party (SLPP) Alliance staged a peaceful protest over perceived activities by the Political Party Registration Commission (PPRC) to destabilise their party.

Report that people in Kenema have burnt government property (including the Forest Industry Canteen, the local administrative court barray and the Maternity Ward at the government hospital) to register their grievances to authorities.
Four students of the National Islamic Primary School, Nyekehun Section in Bunumbu, Kailahun, were injured when a bomb exploded in the schoolyard.
APC supporters allegedly violently ambushed and attacked three SLPP representatives in Tonkolili's Bumbuna while monitoring and observing the by-election polls in the area.
Police arrested eight suspected SLPP supporters during the by-election at Katombo in Tonkolili for alleged disorderly behaviour and possession of offensive weapons.
Over 200 land-holding families of the Gambia Mattru Oil Palm Estate converged at the Court Barray in Bonthe district's Mattru Jong to protest corruption and tribalism among project leaders.

column6: Police Forces of Sierra Leone (2007-2018) Prison Guards
column17: Prison guards at the Pademba road Correctional Centre in Freetown allegedly beat up an inmate, leaving him injured.

A suspected gunman from neighbouring Cariland town in Liberia shot at rangers on their regular patrol at the Gola forest in Nomo chiefdom, Kenema district, of Sierra Leone, leaving one of them severely injured. The attack came in the context of recent arrests in connection to illegal mining and hunting activities.
Njala University students in Freetown protested against protracted delays in the resumption of lectures for the Freetown, Njala and Bo campuses for the past three months.
Women in from Bombali, Kambia and Port Loko districts converged in Brookfields, Freetown, to voice out their concerns on the state of education in their districts.
Hundreds of residents within the American Embassy and IMATT community protested along Abayomie Cole Avenue to protest uncertainties over the status of their houses following a land dispute.
Students from Njala university and supporters protested in Bo, Kenema, Freetown, and Makeni over the government's failure to re-open the university since November 2016.
Students from Njala university and supporters protested in Bo, Kenema, Freetown, and Makeni over the government's failure to re-open the university since November 2016.

Students from Njala university and supporters protested in Bo, Kenema, Freetown, and Makeni over the government's failure to re-open the university since November 2016. In Bo, police fired tear gas and live bullets after some of the protesters started to vandalise properties, leaving one student killed and several others injured.

column7: Students (Sierra Leone); NPD: National Progressive Democrats
column17: Students from Njala university and supporters protested in Bo, Kenema, Freetown, and Makeni over the government's failure to re-open the university since November 2016. In one instance in Freetown, students erected road blocks near the presidential lodge on State Hill, and police intervened to disperse them. 35 students were arrested following the protests, including a co-founding member of the newly accepted National Progressive Democrats (NPD) party.

Rioters attacked and hurt staff of the National Tourist Board along Lumley beach late March, damaging the board's building, pointing that the land where the Board building is situated belongs to their family. At least 10 were arrested and charged with felony, wounding, assault and riotous conduct.

Assaillants carried out looting, rioting and sporadic attacks on cars and people throwing stones during Easter celerations along the Kissy road in Freetown. 17 were arrested in connection with the event.

On 1 June 2017, a group of youths attacked an INGO staff member in Neya town (Falaba, Northern). This resulted from a spillover of violence from an earlier incident on a motorbike rider who was assigned to the INGO local staff member. The community youth had earlier accused the motorbike rider of assaulting an adolescent who threw an object at him. They tried to attack the motorbike rider, but he received protection in a police station. The youths decided to attack the INGO local staff member instead. [size=no report]
Clean-up volunteers following a mudslide protest, demanding compensation. Sources dated 29/08, though the exact date of the protest is not known.
On 11 October, SLPP supporters stabbed a journalist after forcing news reporters to leave parliament

On 10 October, supporters of the opposition Sierra Leone People's Party (SLPP) attacked the headquarters of the ruling All People's Congress (APC) in Freetown. Some APC officials and supporters who were in their headquarters were trapped inside there for over an hour as SLPP supporters pelted it with stones, and bottles.

column7: SLUDI: Sierra Leone Union on Disabilities Issues
column17: On Monday 24 October 2017, disabled people took to the streets of Freetown in a peaceful protest over the lack of Disability Commission subvention.
The leadership of the opposition Sierra Leone People's Party (SLPP) has condemned the stabbing to death of one of their supporters at Ogoo farm in Western of Freetown over the weekend.

Violence broke out on Monday in the central Freetown between supporters of the opposition Sierra Leone Peoples Party (SLPP) and the ruling All Peoples Congress (APC) over a radio talk show. The fight started after opposition supporters claimed they were marginalized in the talk show at Sierra LeoneBroadcasting Corporation (SLBC).
On January 26, in Pujehun town (Pujehun, Southern), SLPP partisans marched through the town throwing stones at the homes of APC supporters and threatening to kill them.
On January 26, in Kono district (Eastern), APC and SLPP groups clashed over elections, leaving eight people injured and a vehicle burned.

56 people believed to be involved in riotous conduct following the nomination rally of the All Peoples Congress (APC) were arrested: the gangs would disguise as APC or SLPP supporters and take part in rallies.
All People's Congress ( APC ) rallies were reported in Kambia, Port Loko, Kabala, Bo, Kenema, Pujehun and Kono.
On February 14, in Kono town (Kono, Eastern), a car driven by a known member of the APC drove into a crowd of C4C supporters. The number of injuries was not reported.

A well-organised attack on SLPP members and supporters took place in Tokeh on Sunday, 18th February 2018. The Deputy Minister of Trade and Industry, Mr. Ibrahim Washinghai Mansaray took APC thugs to Tokeh before the arrival of the SLPP Presidential Candidate, Julius Maada Bio and many supporters were attacked and arrested.
In Kamalo, the entourage of the opposition Sierra Leone People's Party (SLPP) candidate, Mr Julius Maada Bio, came under attack, leading to destruction of vehicles and injuries of his supporters.
There have been reports of retaliatory attacks in opposition strongholds against APC supporters.
On February 27, in Bo town (Bo, Kakua), APC and SLPP groups clashed over elections. The number of injuries was not reported.
The SLPP Candidate for Constituency 108, was allegedly physically attacked at his residence and that properties worth millions were stolen with the house vandalised in Waterloo.

SLPP members were seriously beaten and wounded by APC thugs. At the time of writing this release, three SLPP members are currently hospitalised in critical conditions suffering from stabbings and broken limbs.
All People's Congress ( APC ) rallies were reported in Kambia, Port Loko, Kabala, Bo, Kenema, Pujehun and Kono.
All People's Congress ( APC ) staged its final rally in the Sierra Leone capital. The large APC crowd, after marching through the city, converged at the Siaka Stevens Stadium.
All People's Congress ( APC ) rallies were reported in Kambia, Port Loko, Kabala, Bo, Kenema, Pujehun and Kono.
All People's Congress ( APC ) rallies were reported in Kambia, Port Loko, Kabala, Bo, Kenema, Pujehun and Kono.
All People's Congress ( APC ) rallies were reported in Kambia, Port Loko, Kabala, Bo, Kenema, Pujehun and Kono.

On 28 February 2018, the SLPP East District Chairman was attacked at his residence by a group of APC thugs led by Abubakarr Fofana, APC Candidate for Member of Parliament in Constituency 107. They claimed that the chairman's personal vehicle was burnt. No report of injuries.
On 28 February 2018, reports indicated an attack on the entourage of the APC presidential candidate.
All People's Congress ( APC ) rallies were reported in Kambia, Port Loko, Kabala, Bo, Kenema, Pujehun and Kono.
All People's Congress ( APC ) rallies were reported in Kambia, Port Loko, Kabala, Bo, Kenema, Pujehun and Kono.

In Bo, the house of the SLPP District Public Relations officer was physically attacked by a group of APC thugs in the Presence of Police Superintendent Mohamed Turay alias 'Yate Yate'. Yate and other Operational Support Division officers physically attacked SLPP District Public Relations officer and beat him up.

The APC accused members of the NGC in Kambia district in northern Sierra Leone of attacking the country's chief of staff while he was there to campaign. The chief of staff's convoy was allegedly attacked with stones, and his vehicle got into an accident due to roadblocks, forcing him to flee for his life.

Violent confrontation between supporters of the ruling APC and opposition SLPP parties. Police received a complaint from SLPP supporters of an attack by APC, with a counter report by the APC against the SLPP.Three houses have been damaged with two belonging to SLPP members and one to an APC member. No injuries reported.
Woman staged a Peace March: they visited political party headquarters and appealed to them to keep the polls free of violence.
Non-violent activity: On 7 March, police allegedly raided the home of SLPP candidate Bio after polls closed on the day of the first round. The opposition accused police forces of siding with the APC.
Riot police were deployed to the streets of the capital Freetown, with Chief Superintendent Mohamed Bangura confirming two arrests after scuffles involving rival parties.
Rival supporters clashed in Freetown on Saturday after results from Sierra Leone's presidential election.
On the week of 12 March, several clashes between political supporters were reported in Port Loko, Kono, Kailahun.
On the week of 12 March, several clashes between political supporters were reported in Port Loko, Kono, Kailahun.
On the week of 12 March, a member of the electoral commission was attacked and wounded in Bo.

On 12 March, violent clashes between supporters of the ruling APC and the main opposition SLPP at Koquima in Kono District. The police local unit commander, Bockarie Sandy says there have been injuries and 18 arrests. Joint military and police patrols were set up.
On the week of 12 March, several clashes between political supporters were reported in Port Loko, Kono, Kailahun.

On 13 March there were reports of several people injured when youths the police described as thieves attacked traders at a popular business district in Freetown and took away their wares. One person was reported dead, although the police have refuted that.
On March 17, in Lumley town (Western Urban, Western), APC supporters attacked two SLPP activists with knives, seriously injuring one.
On 24 March, Sam Sumana (APC) vehicle was attacked by some rioters in Kono.
On 26 March, APC supporters' demonstration was dispersed by police in Monda.
On 3 April, APC thugs attacked a lady who severely injured and brought ot the hospital.

column6: Military Forces of Sierra Leone (2007-2018) Presidential Security Unit
column17: On 31 March, alleged protection officers of President Koroma opened fire against the residence of SLPP presidential candidate, Maada Bio. No fatality reported.

On 31 March 2018, a journalist was beaten whilst covering the presidential run-off election in Freetown. Sources indicate that APC supporters, acting under the instructions of senior APC officials, were responsible for the violence. The victim died on June 6th, reportedly as a result of his injuries.

On 31 March, suspected political ""opponents"" attacked a pick-up with stones, before police opened fire in Lumley in Freetown. Several people were beaten-up. 15 people were arrested. The incident came as the second round of elections was launched.
On 2 April, a supporter of the SLPP candidate was shot by armed OSD officer (police) close to the residence of the SLPP Presidential Candidate.
On 3 April, SLPP supporters demonstrated in front of the law court against the APC intention to rule injunction on NEC.
On 4 April , APC supporters gathered in Freetown to protest what they said was a ""stolen"" presidential vote, hours before official results are expected.
On 4 April night, SLPP supporters of the newly elected president destroyed hundreds of makeshift market stalls used by street traders in Freetown.

Security Measures: On 5 April, police forces declared an 8pm-6am curfew in Makeni and Magburaka, northern Sierra Leone. Police said the indefinite order is due to fears of confrontation and tension among rival political party supporters.

On 5 April, police forces and supporters of the SLPP party clashed in Kenema, Eastern Region. Rioters reportedly slashed windows, disarmed a police officer and attacked the residence of the former internal affairs minister, Sengu Koroma. Several policemen and rioters were injured by gunshots. 2 dead are reported among the SLPP supporters. Some clashes also reportedly occurred with unknown people believed to be APC supporters.
On 6 April, an SLPP supporter was attacked in Makeni by APC thugs and was taken to the hospital.
On 6 April, SLPP supporters and police clashed and gunshots were heard. Civilians had to be taken to the hospital.
Around 10 April, report of attacks by ruling party supporters on opposition supporters in Kono district forced hundreds of people to flee.
On April 22, in Daru town (Kailahun, Eastern), a person was shot dead during a clash between police and bike riders when the police fired tear gas and live bullets.

On 25 April, there was a scuffle in Parliament as APC MPs refused to leave the House despite a High Court injuction against 16 of them and chanted their party's slogans, and the police who intervened to disperse them.
Around 28 April, APC supporters severely injured two alleged SLPP supporters in two separate incidents near their headquarters in Freetown.
Around 28 April, APC supporters severely injured two alleged SLPP supporters in two separate incidents near their headquarters in Freetown.
On 23 May, the APC Mayor of Freetown was beaten by SLPP thugs in Freetown.
On 26 May, APC Zonal Chairman for Malama was allegedly murdered by SLPP men in Freetown.

On 31 May, students in the School of Community and Health Sciences at Njala University, Kowama Campus, Bo, have staged a peaceful protest to express their anger over what they described as a poor learning environment.
On July 5, in Freetown town (Western Urban, Western), Sierra Leone's former Vice President Victor Foh of APC and former Mines Minister Minkailu Mansaray were arrested on charges of corruption.
On 9 July, tollgate workers blocked the tollgates linking Freetown to the rest of the country to protest against bad working conditions. Police intervened to open the gates.

On 17 July, Edmond Abu, head of the Native Consortium and Research Center, led a small unauthorised march against the rise of fuel prices in Freetown. Police dispersed the protest and arrested the man.
On September 9, in Yonibana Chiefdom (Tonkolili District, Northern), police raided the village and killed a man for unknown reasons.

On September 29, in Kambia district (Northern), SLPP and APC groups clashed over political violence related to an ongoing by-election, leaving 1-5 people dead. The by-election was suspended as a result.
On September 29, in Tonko Limba Chiefdom (Kambia, Northern), police raided the village and killed a small boy for unknown reasons.

29 September 2018: The editor of Awareness Times newspaper, John Korama was assaulted by vigilantes of the ruling SLPP in the full glare of the police and the Chairman of the SLPP, while he was covering a bye-election at mile-14 in Tonko Limba.
17 October. Sierra Rutile Iluka mine has closed after the protest by workers demanding that one of their supervisor's should be dismissed for racism.

On October 28, in Koidu city (Kono, Eastern), SLPP and C4C (a faction of APC) clashed during separate inaugurations of their Chair ladies of the Kono Market Women Executive. The number of injuries was not reported.

On October 30, in Malen Chiefdom (Pujehun, Southern), youths staged a demonstration against the harvesting of palm trees on what they say is their land. They mobilized and mounted illegal road blocks and threatened locals with machetes. Police attempted to intervene and youths pelted police officers with stones.

On October 31st, a team from the Ministry of Lands, Housing and Urban Planning - including two ministers - were attacked by a mob at Mongaba, who threw stones at the group (coordinates for Grafton, Freetown, used). Six people have been arrested in connection with the incident.
04 November. Junior doctors from two public hospitals in Freetown have stated their protest demanding higher salaries and better working conditions.

On 5 November 2018 (or around), a group of Muslim youths set fire to a gas station in Lumley neighbourhood of Freetown city (Western Urban, Western), because their access to a local Mosque was impeded by the gas station. The station was partially burnt down. The police forces intervened and used tear gas and live rounds to curtail the situation. [size=no report]
07 November 2018: A house owned by SLPP was burned down by a group of APC supporters who came from Kenema.
On November 12th, police and military (with the latter being from the Joint Medical Unit) clashed in eastern Freetown, over a traffic dispute. Four police officers were beaten by the soldiers.

column7: MUN: Mineworkers Union of Sierra Leone
column17: 22 November. Members of the Mine Workers Union protested at the Sierra Rutile Iluka mine in protest of four executive members being suspended after the October 2018 protest. The executive members are accused of not handing in a 21 day notice before the strike.
On December 15th, between three and four hundred demonstrators (including the First Lady of Sierra Leone) marched in Freetown, against violent assault and sexual violence directed against women.
26 December. APC supporters protest against arbitrary government arrests by marching to the Criminal Investigations Department in Freetown.
28 December. Police arrest former defence minister, Alfred Paolo Conteh and his deputy, Sannah Marrah, in a Anti-Corruption Campaign by President Bio.
29 December. Hundreds of APC supporters protest in Freetown over intimidation, arrest and harassment by the SLPP government. Police intervene with tear gas and make several arrests.

31 December. APC supporters protest against the government's arbitrary arrests in Freetown. Police fire tear gas and live rounds at supporters, injuring several with gunshot wounds and arresting ""dozens"".
07 January. Government police forces barricade entrances to APC party headquarters.
16 January. Thousands of APC supporters gather in Makeni in support of Former President Koroma and APC officials during a cross examination by police. Reports of threats against journalists.

21 January. Two people in Sahn village of Malen chiefdom are killed by police after an intervention likely associated with a protest against the Socfin agribusiness. Independent political Member of Parliament, Siaka Sama, is arrested for inciting the protest.

21 January. Police forces clash with Poro Society in Sahn Malen of Pujehun. Several reports claim police engaged in beating villagers, making arrests including of a local MP, ransacking homes and leading to the death of two civilians. Many flee from the area to escape the violence. The government blames the deaths on secret societies, while others blame police forces.
21 January. SLPP party members attack the Sierra Epress Media office in Kissy area of Freetown, badly injuring the editor.
22 January. 8 Sierra Rutile Mining workers and their driver are kidnapped in Moriba Town on the border of Bonthe and Moyamba Districts by Poro Society members and forcibly added to their ranks.
24 January. Poro Society break into the police station in Lilema near Kenema to free those jailed following clashes three days prior and subsequent government ban on secret societies.
25 January. Police forces beat a civilian for loitering, he died in custody the same day.

column16: African Young Voices; Sierra Express Media
column17: 30 January. A group of 5 police officers arrest and rape a woman in Bo while she was in custody.

02 February. After SLPP security guard stabs Gibril Bangura, a relative of the Information Minister, during President Bio's visit to Kailahun district (coded in a separate evnt), riots erupt at the police station by party members. This may be a part of an ongoing internal SLPP power struggle.

02 February. An SLPP security guard stabs Gibril Bangura, a relative of the Information Minister, during President Bio's visit to Kailahun district. This may be a part of an ongoing internal SLPP power struggle.
14 February. Youths riot and clash with police in Rokel outside Freetown after 2 children are found dead.

17 March. Civilians riot in an attempt to carry out mob justice after an Indian civilian and a group of Sierra Leone civilians cut out the tongue of a youth. Police forces disperse rioters with tear gas. [Size=large crowd]
30 March. A military sergeant shoots and kills his commanding military officer in Freetown over poor working conditions. The sergeant is arrested and held in Freetown.

17 April. Youths riot against the government minister and team involved in Land, Housing and the Environment by throwing stones in Masimbo area of Makeni in Bombali during land reclamation. [size=no report]

24 April. The governments of Guinea and Sierra Leone negotiate for the re-integration and transfer of control of the border town of Yenga in Kailahun from Guinea to Sierra Leone, which Guinea had claimed since the war of the 1990s.

column9: NYC: National Youth Coalition; Journalists (Sierra Leone)
column17: 02 May. Military forces and SLPP supporters assault and beat a Sierra Express Media journalist and another civilian head of the NYC following an APC walkout from Parliament in Freetown.

06 May. 300 members of a communal militia with machetes, knives and sticks in Dema island attack around 100 civilians in Bomatoke of Dema. Communal militia members injure civilians, loot and destroy property before police intervene to make arrests. [size=300]
Week of 15 May. Students at the Muslim Brotherhood Secondary School rioted against police forces when police entered the campus to make arrests for exam malpractice. [size=no report]
24 May. Students protest over poor school administration at African Methodist Collegiate School in Freetown. [size=no report]

29 May. Students riot at African Methodist Collegiate School in Freetown over poor school administration with police intervening with tear gas and making arrests to disrupt the riot. Students threw rocks at police forces and constructed barricades on the road. [size=at least 25]
30 May. APC members protest in Freetown against a court ruling to remove APC MPs from Parliament. [size=a handful]

31 May. APC members riot by throwing stones at police forces near APC headquarters in Freetown following the court ruling of removal of 10 APC members from Parliament. Police intervene by firing tear gas and arresting dozens of APC supporters, with others reportedly injured. [size=dozens]
31 May. Police arrested and ""brutalized"" APC supporters at their party headquarters in Freetown, arresting 145 people.

25 June. Supporters of two opposing Fourah Bay College Student Union candidates riot against one another in Freetown at the college campus. Police intervene by firing tear gas to disrupt the riot. [size=no report]
01 July. Protesters from the fishing industry in Freetown demonstrated against increases in fishing license fees. [size=no report]
21 July. An unidentified armed group attacks a Nigerian judge at his home outside Freetown. The judge is involved in the investigation of the former president, Ernest Bai Koroma.
25 July. Police forces assaulted civilians and made several arrests due to disagreements in the location of a police checkpoint in Combema, Nongowa.

29 July. SLPP and APC members clashed in Hamilton, Western Area ahead of August 24th elections. Vehicles are burned, injuries reported and police arrest the deputy organizing secretary of the APC. [size=no report]

07 August. Students demonstrated in Bo, Kakua following the mandate that all fees must be paid in order to take exams. Police intervened, severely beating several students during their intervention. [size=no report]
09 August. Taama and Nyandeama communal militias clashed over a land dispute in Nyandeyama, Eastern. 3 were injured, a woman was raped, goods looted and property destroyed in the clash.
13 August. Police arrested the APC chairman of the Western Rural area and held him without bail at a prison in Freetown. His exact arrest location is unknown.
Weekend of 17-18 August. An unidentified armed group broke into the chambers of a female magistrate in Freetown, Western. This may be connected to ongoing break-ins with judges in the country.
Weekend of 17-18 August. An unidentified armed group broke into the chambers of a female magistrate in Bo, Southern. This may be connected to ongoing break-ins with judges in the country.
19 August. The former mayor of Freetown and APC member was arrested by police forces. This was likely a politically motivated arrest.
20 August. Local elections in Falaba, Sulima led to violence between APC and SLPP supporters. Police intervened to disperse the groups and make arrests. [size=no report]

24 August. APC and SLPP supporters disrupted voting in Freetown constituency 110 in Angola Town. A polling station was destroyed and voting materials destroyed. APC and SLPP members blame each other as responsible for the event. [size=no report]
29 August. Richard Konteh, an APC leader and State House Chief of Staff, was arrested and detained following statements he made about the elections.
On September 9, 2019, Labour Group from Fourah Bay College protested in Freetown over delays in the payment of their salaries. [size=no report]

On an unspecified date around September 12, 2019, 3 people were wounded when Taama Communal Militia attacked Nyandeama village in Kono district [unfound location, coded: Koidu, capital city of Kono District] over land dispute.
On October 3, 2019, angry youths protested by gathering in Moyamba and blocking the major roads and preventing the launch of a Chinese bauxite mining project. [size=no report]

On October 16, 2019, some members of a Bike Riders Union staged a demonstration in Makeni. They thew stones at the offices of Sierra Leone Roads Safety Authority and damaged the building as they were expressing discontent against alleged extortion of monies from them by the new road safety corps. The Police and Military subsequently intervened and fired tear gas at demonstrators. [size=no report]
On October 25, 2019, worshipers of Basharia Mosque in Freetown prevented Sierra Leonean Vice President Juldeh Jalloh from making a speech after the Friday's prayers. [size=no report]

On November 19, 2019, workers of the Sierra Leone Standards Bureau (SLSB) protested in Freetown (Western Area Urban, Western), against their poor conditions of service, and the lack of equipment. [size=no report]

column9: NGC: National Grand Coalition; Journalists (Sierra Leone)
column17: On November 23, 2019, in Kasiri town (Kambia, Northern Region), a group of unidentified men suspected to be supporters of the SLPP political party engaged in violence against some supporters of NGC opposition party, including journalists and two leaders of the party, Kandeh Kolleh Yumkella and Dennis Bright who were reportedly injured. This happened in the context of parliamentary bye-elections. [size=no report]

On 3 December 2019, a group of youths barricaded Sierra Tropical Company and stopped the company's normal activities in Sumbuya, Bo District (Southern). This occurred after the company neglected a list of people the local authorities submitted for employment, following a previous agreement. No fatalities and/or injuries reported. The expatriate and senior staff of the company left the area after the locals threatened to attack them. [size=no report]

column7: APC: All Peoples Congress; Former Police Forces of Sierra Leone (2007-2018)
column17: On 4 January 2020, a fight broke out over a land dispute between the bodyguard of a SLPP political party parliamentary candidate and a former police officer in Freetown city, Freetown1 subdivision (Western Area Urban, Western). The former police officer was later arrested. He claims that his arrest is politically motivated as he served as the aide-de-camp of the former APC (now opposition) President Ernest Bai Koroma. No fatality and/or casualty reported. [size=no report]

On 7 Jan. 2020, a group of students of the Limkokwing College of Science and Technology staged a protest in Hill Station, Freetown1 subdivision (Western Area Urban, Western), to demand the payment of their tuition grants by the university. The police intervened and fired tear gas at the protesters. 17 protesters were arrested according to the police (18 arrested according to the students). [size=at least 17]

column16: Whatsapp; Cocorioko; Sierra Leone Broadcasting Corporation; Sierra Leone Telegraph
column17: On 14 Jan. 2020, a violent confrontation broke out between the supporters of SLPP ruling party and APC opposition, in Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western). The clashes broke out after a group of SLPP supporters reportedly threw stones at APC supporters when a funeral cortege carrying the remains of a senior SLPP supporter drove by the APC party headquarters. Several people were injured, and one of them died of his wounds. The police forces were present in the location, but did not intervene. [size=at least several]

column16: Front Page Africa; African Young Voices; All Africa; AFP
column17: On 15 Jan. 2020, the police forces briefly arrested the Liberian leader of the Council of Patriots (COP) in Freetown Airport (Western Urban Area, Western), after Liberian authorities reportedly asked for him to return to Liberia.

column16: Politico SL; Sierra Network Online; African Young Voices
column17: On 17 Jan. 2020, a group of students of the Milton Margai College of Education and Technology (MMCET) staged a protest in Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western) against what they say the undue delay by the authorities to transform their college into a Technical University. [size=no report]

column7: APC: All Peoples Congress; SLPP: Sierra Leone Peoples Party
column16: Umaru Fofana; Global Times; Sierra Express Media; Sierra Leone Telegraph; African Young Voices; Undisclosed Source; Cocorioko
column17: On 26 Jan. 2020, violence escalated in the headquarters of the SLPP ruling party and then in the streets of Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western), after an attack by suspected supporters of the APC party (opposition) according to the SLPP. 27 people were reportedly injured. The police forces later arrested 15 suspects linked to the incident including one leader of APC party. The APC dismissed the accusation and said this was in internal clash within SLPP. [size=at least 27]

On 29 Jan. 2020 (or around), violence erupted between students of the Fourah Bay University in Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western), after the cancellation of the Law Department Presidential Election. [size=no report]

On 31 Jan. 2020, a group of students of Fourah Bay University demonstrated in Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western) against the high increases in tuition fees, lack of transportation and inadequate lecture rooms and hostels. [size=no report]
On 31 Jan. 2020 (or around), a group of bus drivers staged a protest in Bo town, Kakua subdivision (Bo, Southern), to denounce suspicious deductions from their monthly salaries. [size=no report]

column16: African Young Voices; Politico SL; Sierra Leone Telegraph; Awoko
column17: On 1 Feb. 2020, a group of about 40 young men attempted to enter the property of the deputy minister of internal affairs in Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western). The security officer [coded: Police Force] fired a warning shot to disperse them, and then shot and injured one young man who was insisting in forcing the gate. Three people were later arrested in relation with that incident. [size=about 40]

On 8 Feb. 2020, a group of students of the Milton Margai College of Education and Technology (MMCET) staged a protest in Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western) against what they say was the undue delay by authorities to transform their college into a Technical University. [size=no report]

On 13 Feb. 2020, unidentified individuals threw stones at and damaged the official vehicle of the Minister of Local Government and Rural Development which was driving along the Makeni highway, near Makare village in Bombali Sebora subdivision (Bombali, Northern). The circumstances and reasons of that attack remain unclear. [size=no report]
On 21 Feb. 2020 (or around), a group of students of the Fourah Bay University demonstrated in Freetown (Western Area Urban, Western) over the shortage of graduation regalia. [size=no report]

On 22 Feb. 2020, a group of unidentified individuals suspected to be Guinean mercenaries attacked the embassy of Guinea in Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western). They reportedly fired shots in the air, disarmed and beat a Sierra Leonean police guard, and destroyed some voting materials. One of the assailants was killed and another injured, and six arrested as they fled.

On 27 Feb. 2020, a group of civil society organisations calling itself Native Consortium staged a protest at the Parliament in Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western) against high cost of living and joblessness among other claims. [size=no report]

column16: African Young Voices; Patriotic Vanguard; Sierra Leone Telegraph; Sierra Network Online
column17: On 5 March 2020, a group of students of the Limkokwing University of Creative Technology staged a protest in Freetown city (Western Area Urban, Western), to demand that the government honour the previous government's fee payment for students on a government grant. The police forces intervened and arrested 40 students, as well as the leader of the Citizens Advocacy Network (CAN) who was taking part in the demonstration. [size=at least 40]

On 13 March 2020, a group of nurses demonstrated in Mountain Cut community, Freetown (Western Area Urban, Western) to denounce poor working conditions and an unfriendly relationship with a newly appointed medical superintendent in their hospital. [size=no report]

On 16 March 2020, a group of nurses demonstrated in Mountain Cut community, Freetown (Western Area Urban, Western) to denounce poor working conditions and unfriendly relationship with a newly appointed medical superintendent in their hospital. [size=no report]

On 17 March 2020, residents clashed with a group of police officers during a demonstration against a security operation in Mano village (Bonthe, Southern). Some police officers were reportedly injured, and one went missing. A statement of the Police Media says the missing officer was beaten to death according to unconfirmed reports. 11 people were reportedly arrested in connection with this incident. [size=at least 11]

column16: Sierra Leone Telegraph; Cocorioko; Xinhua; Sierra Network Online; Agence de Presse Africaine; Umaru Fofana
column17: On 24 March 2020, the government of Sierra Leone declared a 12 month state of emergency to prevent and combat the coronavirus. The government issued a new directive on 11 April, imposing a curfew from 9 p.m to 6 a.m.

On 2 April 2020, the military forces beat up and injured a journalist in Kenema town, Nongowa subdivision (Kenema, Eastern). The incident took place at a potential coronavirus quarantine venue were the victim was denied entrance. The soldiers started to beat him when he took photos of the place.
